title: Zepsa Construction, Inc. v. Randazzo
description: In this action to foreclose a mechanic's lien, overhead expenses and lost profits were not recoverable as lienable items given the construction project had not been completed and the parties had not agreed upon these items as terms of the contract.  The prevailing party was entitled to an award of attorney's fees under the mechanic's lien statute.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Zepsa Construction, Inc,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Phillip A. Randazzo and Virginia M.
Randazzo,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John Buford Grier, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 3673
Heard May 13, 2003 â€“ Filed September 
  15, 2003
Withdrawn, Substituted and Re-filed 
  January 7, 2004

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Douglas Gay, of Rock Hill; for Appellants.
S. Jackson Kimball, III, of Rock Hill; for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, J.:Â  In this action to foreclose 
  a mechanicâ€™s lien, the master ordered judgment against Phillip and Virginia 
  Randazzo in the amount of $50,846.00, and awarded attorneyâ€™s fees to Zepsa in 
  the amount of $8,123.40.Â  The Randazzos appeal, arguing the master erred in:Â  
  (1) including lost profits and overhead in the amount of the mechanicâ€™s lien; 
  and (2) awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Zepsa.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
Phillip and Virginia Randazzo (collectively, 
  â€œRandazzosâ€), owned and operated an Italian restaurant near Tega Cay Village 
  Shopping Center in Fort Mill, South Carolina.Â  In September 1996, they contacted 
  Ed Zepsa, president of Zepsa Construction, Inc. (â€œZepsaâ€) to inquire about the 
  design and construction of a new restaurant.Â  After several months of discussions 
  and negotiations, the parties entered into on May 14, 1997, a written construction 
  contract for Zepsa to build the restaurant.Â  The agreed price was $610,000.00.Â  
  The terms of the contract required a deposit in the amount of $61,000.00 to 
  be paid when the contract was signed.Â  
On May 29, 1997, the Randazzos gave written 
  â€œnotice to proceedâ€ with construction.Â  At that time, they provided Zepsa with 
  a check for $21,000.00, representing part of the agreed deposit.Â  Zepsa did 
  not begin work at this time because the Randazzos had not paid the full deposit.Â  
  By letter dated July 1, 1997, Zepsa agreed to accept the remainder of the deposit 
  in two installments.Â  These installments were to be paid at the time of the 
  first two payment requests after construction began. Â Zepsa began work on the 
  site on July 7, 1997.Â  Between July 15 and August 2, 1997, Virginia Randazzo 
  (Virginia) spoke by phone with either Ed Zepsa or the project manager on four 
  occasions.Â  During these conversations, she asked about terminating the contract 
  due to the Randazzosâ€™ marital problems, instructed Zepsa to stop work, and told 
  Zepsa to continue to delay construction while the Randazzos tried to resolve 
  their marital difficulties.Â  On August 3, Virginia called Ed Zepsa and told 
  him she did not want to continue with the project.Â  
On August 4, the Randazzos contacted Ed 
  Zepsa and instructed him to proceed with construction.Â  In response, he submitted 
  a payment request seeking payment of $8,674.00 for work that had been performed 
  and $40,000.00 for the balance of the deposit.Â  Also on August 4, Zepsa received 
  a letter from the Randazzosâ€™ attorney requesting that Zepsa abide by the deposit 
  payment schedule and proceed with the work.Â  Zepsa resumed work on the project.Â  
  Â Â 
On August 11, Zepsa submitted a payment 
  request for work performed through July and included a request for the next 
  deposit installment. Â No payment was made for this completed work or the deposit 
  installments.Â  By letter dated August 28, 1997, the Randazzosâ€™ attorney gave 
  notice of termination of the contract. Â Â Â Â 
Zepsa timely filed a lis pendens and complaint 
  on October 16, 1997.Â  The complaint sought judgment against the Randazzos and 
  foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s lien that Zepsa had previously filed and served.Â  
  The matter was referred with finality to the master.Â  At the hearing, Zepsa 
  presented uncontested evidence that Zepsa performed construction work on the 
  job site in the amount of $10,846.00. Â In his order dated January 22, 2001, 
  the master granted Zepsa judgment against the Randazzos in the amount of $50,846.00, 
  which included the unpaid balance for work already performed and payment for 
  the remaining deposit balance of $40,000.00.Â  By order dated March 22, 2001, 
  the master awarded Zepsa attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $8,123.40, and costs 
  in the amount of $1,490.60.Â  The Randazzos appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to foreclose a mechanicâ€™s lien is a law case in 
  South Carolina.â€Â  Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc. v. Palmieri, 345 S.C. 
  550, 553, 548 S.E.2d 900, 901 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œIn an action at law, tried 
  without a jury, the judgeâ€™s findings will not be disturbed unless they are without 
  evidentiary support.â€Â  King v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 317 S.C. 385, 388, 
  453 S.E.2d 885, 888 (1995).Â  â€œHis findings are equivalent to those of a jury 
  in an action at law.â€Â  Id. at 389, 453 S.E.2d at 888.
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Mechanicâ€™s Lien
The Randazzos argue the master erred by including 
  lost profits in the amount of the mechanicâ€™s lien when only a small portion 
  of the contract work was actually performed.Â Â Â  
Section 29-5-10 of the South Carolina 
  Code of Laws defines a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (1991 & 
  Supp. 2002). [1] Â  This section 
  provides in pertinent part:

(a) A person to whom a debt is due for labor performed or 
  furnished or for materials furnished and actually used in the erection, alteration, 
  or repair of a building or structure upon real estate or the boring and equipping 
  of wells, by virtue of an agreement with, or by consent of, the owner of the 
  building or structure, or a person having authority from, or rightfully acting 
  for, the owner in procuring or furnishing the labor or materials shall have 
  a lien upon the building or structure and upon the interest of the owner of 
  the building or structure in the lot of land upon which it is situated to secure 
  the payment of the debt due to him.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (1991).Â  
In the instant case, the master granted a judgment 
  against the Randazzos in the amount of $50,846.00 based on two grounds.Â  First, 
  the master found Zepsaâ€™s lost profits and overhead expenses were recoverable 
  as an element of damages for the Randazzosâ€™ breach of the construction contract.Â  
  Secondly, the master concluded â€œthese elements of damage [were also] recoverable 
  in a mechanicâ€™s lien foreclosure action.â€ Â The master reasoned:

Since Zepsa is entitled to profits and overhead expenses, 
  there is a reasonable and equitable basis for claiming the balance of the deposit 
  as an integral part of the payment due under the contract, unrelated to actual 
  work performed.Â  Thus, Zepsa is entitled to be paid the balance of the deposit 
  due, along with the balance due for work which was performed.

Given Zepsaâ€™s recovery in its mechanicâ€™s 
  lien action is limited to that as provided for in the mechanicâ€™s lien statute, 
  the question becomes whether the overhead expenses and lost profits were lienable 
  items.Â  In concluding these items were recoverable under a mechanicâ€™s lien, 
  the master relied on our Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Sentry Engâ€™g & Constr., 
  Inc. v. Marinerâ€™s Cay Dev. Corp., 287 S.C. 346, 338 S.E.2d 631 (1985).Â  
  In Sentry, a builder, Sentry, and a developer executed two separate agreements 
  for the construction of a condominium.Â  The first agreement provided for the 
  cost of the construction and the second provided for the additional compensation 
  of overhead and profit.Â  As the project neared completion, Sentry filed a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien for balances due under both agreements and change orders.Â  Sentry exercised 
  its right to arbitration and filed a claim in the amount of its mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  
  Sentry later amended its arbitration demand to include claims for damages for 
  wrongful termination of the construction contract.Â  The American Arbitration 
  Association (AAA) found Sentry was entitled to $503,271.00.Â  The circuit court 
  adopted the AAAâ€™s award as a judgment, granted Sentry summary judgment on its 
  mechanicâ€™s lien foreclosure petition, assessed interest, and awarded Sentry 
  attorney fees.
On appeal, the developer raised several 
  issues, including the assertion the circuit court judge erred in holding that 
  profit and overhead were components of â€œdebtâ€ under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute. 
  Id. at 349, 338 S.E.2d 633.Â  Our Supreme Court rejected the developerâ€™s 
  argument.Â  The Court held â€œthat overhead and profit, when stated as part of 
  the contract price, are proper components of a mechanicâ€™s lien.â€Â  Id. 
  at 352, 338 S.E.2d at 635.Â  The Court found that â€œâ€˜[s]uch items, as such and 
  standing by themselves, are nonlienable, but they become lienable when they 
  are included in a contract price or are reflected in the reasonable value of 
  labor or materials furnished.â€™â€ Id. at 352, 338 S.E.2d at 634 (quoting 
  53 Am. Jur. 2d Mechanicsâ€™ Liens Â§ 107 (1970)).
Based on our reading of Sentry, 
  we believe the Supreme Court expanded the items that are recoverable under the 
  mechanicâ€™s lien statute to include overhead and profit.Â  However, this holding 
  is only available in the limited situation where the terms of overhead and profit 
  are agreed upon by the parties and are subsequently embodied within a contract.
In view of the specific facts of the instant 
  case, Sentry is inapplicable for several reasons.Â  Significantly, the 
  parties in Sentry entered into a separate agreement that specifically 
  provided for the recovery of overhead and profit.Â  In contrast, Zepsa and the 
  Randazzos did not execute an agreement providing for overhead and profit.Â  Their 
  contract is silent concerning these items.Â  Even though Ed Zepsa testified the 
  deposit constituted compensation for pre-construction or â€œup frontâ€ work, his 
  testimony is not determinative of the agreed upon terms of the contract.Â  There 
  is no evidence the parties agreed to pay $61,000.00 as an upfront cost.Â  Additionally, 
  the account statement of the contract does not list overhead and profit as terms, 
  but instead indicates the $61,000.00 is an additional amount that represents 
  10% of the $610,000.00 contract price.Â  Furthermore, the construction in Sentry 
  was substantially completed whereas only $10,000.00 of the $610,000.00 Zepsa 
  project had been completed.
Because we find Sentry distinguishable, 
  Zepsa is limited to recovery provided for by the strict terms of the mechanicâ€™s 
  lien statute.Â  This â€œstatute provides that debts for â€˜labor performedâ€™ or â€˜materials 
  furnishedâ€™ are lienable debts.â€Â  Hardin Constr. Group, Inc. v. Carlisle Constr. 
  Co., 300 S.C. 456, 457, 388 S.E.2d 794, 795 (1990); see Johnson 
  v. Barnhill, 279 S.C. 242, 245, 306 S.E.2d 216, 218 (1983) (â€œIn order to 
  establish a mechanicâ€™s lien, it is generally necessary that the labor performed 
  go into something which has attached to and become a part of the real estate, 
  adding to the value thereof.â€); Tenny v. Anderson Water, Light & Power 
  Co., 67 S.C. 11, 17, 45 S.E. 111, 113 (1903) (â€œâ€˜The extent of the remedy 
  afforded by the [mechanicâ€™s lien] act is to enforce the lien upon the property 
  covered.â€™â€ (quoting Johnston v. Frazee, 20 S.C. 500 (1884))).Â  
With respect to overhead and profits, the extent 
  of a contractorâ€™s recovery has been interpreted as follows:

A contractor is only allowed a privilege for claims expressly 
  granted by the statute and equitable considerations do not enlarge such right.Â  
  Generally, overhead costs and lost profits are not within the purview of a mechanicsâ€™ 
  lien statute; but, where overhead costs and profits are provided for in the 
  contract, they become subject to collection on a mechanicâ€™s lien. 

56 C.J.S. Mechanicsâ€™ Liens Â§ 196 (2000).Â Â  

As testified to by Ed Zepsa, the $61,000.00 deposit 
  was not associated with any labor performed.Â  The master also recognized this 
  fact given he stated in his order â€œthere is a reasonable and equitable basis 
  for claiming the balance of the deposit as an integral part of the payment due 
  under the contract, unrelated to actual work performed.â€ Thus, we find the master 
  erred in finding Zepsa was entitled to the balance of this amount under a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien action.Â  Moreover, we note the mechanicâ€™s lien statement of account, which 
  outlines the amount that is recoverable, is not included in the Record on Appeal.Â  
  Despite this omission from the record, there is a letter from Zepsaâ€™s attorney 
  to the Randazzosâ€™ attorney that itemizes the amount of Zepsaâ€™s claim.Â  In this 
  accounting, the â€œTotal due on workâ€ is valued at $10,846.00.Â  Accordingly, Zepsaâ€™s 
  recovery under its mechanicâ€™s lien action is limited to $10,846.00, an amount 
  that the parties agree represents the work completed.Â  Â Â Â 
Our decision is consistent with the holdings in 
  other jurisdictions.Â  See, e.g., In re Regâ€™l Bldg. Sys., Inc., 
  273 B.R. 423, 443 (Bankr. D. Md. 2001), affâ€™g 320 F.3d 482 (4th Cir. 
  2003) (â€œ[A] claim for lost profits arising from a breach of contract based on 
  wrongful termination of a contract before construction is completed cannot be 
  asserted as a mechanicâ€™s lien or as a claim payable from contractorâ€™s trust.â€); 
  Tilt-Up Concrete, Inc. v. Star City/Federal, Inc., 582 N.W.2d 604 (Neb. 
  1998) (concurring with other jurisdictions which deny lien for lost profits 
  because they compensate a party for work not yet performed); Fortune v. Million 
  Dev. Co., 768 P.2d 1194, 1197 (Ariz. Ct. App. 1989) (holding that â€œa lien 
  filed before completion of a contract is limited to the value of the labor or 
  services actually furnished at the time the lien is filed . . . rather than 
  the full contract price payable after completion of the contractâ€); Bangor 
  Roofing & Sheet Metal Co. v. Robbins Plumbing Co., 116 A.2d 664 (Me. 
  1955) (recognizing that overhead and lost profit standing by themselves are 
  not lienable); see generally W. J. Dunn, Annotation, Amount For Which 
  Mechanicâ€™s Lien May Be Obtained Where Contract Has Been Terminated or Abandoned 
  by Consent of Parties or Without Fault on Contractorâ€™s Part, 51 A.L.R.2d 
  1009 (1957 & Supp. 2003) (discussing the following methods for valuing a 
  mechanicâ€™s lien where contract had been prematurely terminated:Â  (1) amount 
  of work performed up to the date work was stopped; (2) amount proportional to 
  entire contract price; (3) amount of profit included in lien in limited jurisdictions; 
  (4) amount of profit excluded; and (5) amount includes contract price less amount 
  of completion).
II.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
The Randazzos argue the master erred by 
  awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Zepsa and not to them. 
The Randazzos raise this issue in conjunction 
  with their first issue.Â  They assert that â€œ[i]f this Court reverses the lower 
  courtâ€™s finding regarding the lien, the Appellants will become the prevailing 
  party under the statute.â€Â  The Randazzos do not make any argument that the master 
  erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees other than to contend that because we should 
  reverse on the first issue, we should also reverse the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  

â€œThe determination as to the amount of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees that should be awarded under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute is addressed to 
  the sound discretion of the trial court.â€Â  Keeneyâ€™s Metal Roofing, Inc., 
  345 S.C. 550, 553, 548 S.E.2d 900, 901 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œThe courtâ€™s decision 
  regarding such a matter will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  
  Id.  
In an action to foreclose a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien, the award of attorneyâ€™s fees is governed by section 29-5-10(a).Â  This 
  section states in pertinent part, â€œThe costs which may arise in enforcing or 
  defending against the lien under this chapter, including a reasonable attorneyâ€™s 
  fee, may be recovered by the prevailing party.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) 
  (1991).
Section 29-5-10(b) outlines the procedure 
  for determining the â€œprevailing party.â€Â  The statute in effect at the time of 
  this action provides in relevant part:

For purposes of the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the determination 
  of the prevailing party is based on one verdict in the action.Â  One verdict 
  assumes some entitlement to the mechanicâ€™s lien and the consideration of compulsory 
  counterclaims.Â  The party whose offer is closer to the verdict reached is considered 
  the prevailing party in the action.Â  If the difference between both offers and 
  the verdict is equal, neither party is considered to be the prevailing party 
  for purposes of determining the award of costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.
If the plaintiff makes no written offer of settlement, the 
  amount prayed for in his complaint is considered to be his final offer of settlement.
If the defendant makes no written offer of settlement, the 
  value of his counterclaim is considered to be his negative offer of settlement.Â  
  If the defendant has not asserted a counterclaim, his offer of settlement is 
  considered to be zero.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(b) (Supp. 2002). [2]Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the instant case, Zepsa made a written offer 
  of settlement for $40,000.00.Â  Because the Randazzos did not make an offer of 
  settlement, the value of their counterclaims, $88,000, is considered a negative 
  offer of settlement.Â  As previously discussed, the $40,000.00 deposit should 
  not have been included as part of the mechanicâ€™s lien and, thus, Zepsa should 
  have been awarded $10,864.00.Â  Even excluding the amount of the deposit, Zepsa 
  still remains the prevailing party and was properly awarded attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
  Given the Randazzos do not challenge the amount of the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, 
  we affirm the masterâ€™s decision.
CONCLUSION
In view of the foregoing analysis, we 
  hold the master erred in awarding $50,486.00 to Zepsa for its mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  
  Because the $40,000 balance of the agreed upon deposit, which the parties characterized 
  as overhead expenses and lost profit, was not a term of the construction contract, 
  it was not a proper lienable item under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.Â  The master 
  did, however, correctly award $10,864.00 to Zepsa for the value of work that 
  had been completed on the project.Â  Finally, we affirm the masterâ€™s decision 
  to award Zepsa attorneyâ€™s fees given it was the â€œprevailing partyâ€ under the 
  mechanicâ€™s lien statute.
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED. 
HEARN, C.J. and STILWELL, J., concur. 
  

 
   
    [1] Â  Although we recognize section 29-5-10 was amended in 1999, we cite 
    to the most current version of this subsection given no substantive amendments 
    have been made to the subsection since this litigation began.

 
   
    [2] Â Â  We note section 29-5-10(b) was substantively amended in 1999 and 
    the new version became effective on June 11, 1999.Â  Act No. 83, 1999 S.C. 
    Acts 269.Â  Prior to the amendment, the portion of the statute applicable to 
    settlement offers and the award of attorneyâ€™s fees stated, â€œIf the defendant 
    makes no written offer of settlement, his offer of settlement is considered 
    to be zero.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(b) (1991); see Lauro v. Visnapuu, 
    351 S.C. 507, 570 S.E.2d 551 (Ct. App. 2002), cert. denied (Apr. 24, 
    2003) (discussing determination of prevailing party for award of attorneyâ€™s 
    fees in mechanicâ€™s lien action under pre- and post-amendment version of section 
    29-5-10(b)).Â Â  
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Randazzos do 
    not present any argument concerning which version of the statute is applicable 
    to their case.Â  However, based on the following procedural facts, we find 
    the post-amendment version of the statute governs our analysis in this case.Â  
    Zepsa filed its Complaint on October 16, 1997.Â  The Randazzos filed their 
    Answer and Counterclaim on August 17, 1998, to which a Reply was made on September 
    10, 1998.Â  On November 13, 2000, Zepsa made its offer of settlement.Â  The 
    master entered his final order for judgment and foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s 
    lien on January 22, 2001.Â  Subsequently, the master awarded Zepsa attorneyâ€™s 
    fees by order dated March 22, 2001.Â  Given Zepsa made its offer of 
    settlement and the master awarded attorneyâ€™s fees after the 1999 amendment, 
    we conclude the post-1999 version of the statute is applicable to this case.

State v. Abdullah



THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
       
        The State, Appellant,
      
    
  


v.
 
   
     
       
        Muttaquin Abdullah aka Clayton 
          Pinckney, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland 
  County
  Â L. Henry McKellar, Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3721
  Heard November 5, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 12, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
          Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, and Senior Assistant 
          Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
          Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Assistant Appellate Defender 
          Aileen P. Clare, of S.C. Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for 
          Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Muttaquin 
  Abdullah was indicted for possession with intent to distribute marijuana and 
  possession with intent to distribute marijuana within a one-half mile proximity 
  of a school.Â  In pre-trial proceedings, Abdullah moved to suppress evidence 
  seized in a warrantless search, contending that the search and seizure violated 
  the Fourth Amendment.Â  The circuit court granted the motion to suppress.Â  The 
  State appeals, claiming the circuit court erred in finding a Fourth Amendment 
  violation of Adbullahâ€™s rights. [1] Â  We reverse.
FACTS 

Shortly before 1:00 a.m. on October 
  4, 2000, two officers of the Columbia Police Department, while on uniform patrol, 
  responded to a call regarding a burglary in process at 34-F Bethel Bishop Apartments 
  within the Columbia city limits.Â  While en route, the officers also received 
  a report of â€œshots firedâ€ at the apartment.
Upon arriving at the scene, the officers 
  observed the door to apartment 34-F open, and they entered the doorway.Â  One 
  of the officers, Jesse Carrillo, saw â€œa black male subject in some black shorts 
  or something â€¦ [a]nd when he saw us, he just kind of stood in the door right 
  there and basically refused to come out as we were trying to call him out because 
  we didnâ€™t know who he was.â€Â  The man the officers observed was Abdullah.
The officers sought cooperation from 
  Abdullah, who instead moved near a bedroom door where he stood in a manner such 
  that his left side was shielded from the officersâ€™ view.Â  According to Abdullah, 
  he moved toward the bedroom door so that he could toss into the bedroom a gun 
  left by purported burglars shortly before the officers arrived.
After unsuccessfully â€œpleadingâ€ with 
  Abdullah to cooperate, Officer Carrillo â€œreached in and grabbedâ€ Abdullah in 
  an effort â€œto pull him out of the bedroom.â€Â  A struggle ensued and, due to Abdullahâ€™s 
  superior size and strength, Officer Nelson joined with Officer Carrillo in the 
  struggle.Â  During the struggle, Abdullah announced he was the victim of the 
  burglary and had called 911.Â  The officers intended to handcuff Abdullah with 
  his hands behind him, as required by procedure, but were unable to do so.Â  They 
  eventually managed to handcuff one of his wrists to a chair in the kitchen.Â  
  
At this point, the officers knew 
  neither the accuracy of Abdullahâ€™s claim to be a victim nor the security status 
  of the apartment.Â  They had observed bullet holes outside the apartment door 
  and inside the apartment.Â  As the officers sought Abdullahâ€™s cooperation, they 
  observed bullet holes in the walls of the apartment.Â  Once Abdullah was secured, 
  Officer Carrillo described the officersâ€™ perspective and concerns as follows: 
  

  [W]e donâ€™t know if weâ€™ve got additional 
    victims down that are going to need medical assistance.Â  We donâ€™t know if 
    weâ€™ve got subjects hiding.Â  We donâ€™t know who else is in there.Â  So thatâ€™s 
    why weâ€™ve got to clear it essentially for persons for safety reasons â€¦ we 
    still didnâ€™t know if we had people in there because that was as far as I had 
    gotten â€¦. We didnâ€™t know even at that point if there were more suspects in 
    there â€¦ so we wanted to basically contain the apartment â€¦ with this alleged 
    burglary in progress so that way we could make sure we didnâ€™t have anymore 
    victims in there, anymore suspects.

Consequently, Officer Carrillo conducted 
  a protective sweep of the apartment to search for victims, suspects, and to 
  preserve the crime scene.Â  He went to the doorway of the bedroom where Abdullah 
  had been standing.Â  Light from the kitchen partially illuminated the bedroom, 
  enabling Officer Carrillo to see Adbullahâ€™s previously discarded gun lying on 
  the bed.Â  Officer Carrillo then turned on the bedroom light, at which time he 
  saw money, drug paraphenalia, and bags containing green, leafy material he believed 
  was marijuana. 
Officer Carrillo immediately contacted 
  his supervisor, who obtained a search warrant from a magistrate and summoned 
  narcotics agents.Â  The contraband was seized pursuant to a search warrant, and 
  the green, leafy material was later determined to be marijuana.Â  Abdullah was 
  charged and indicted for possession with intent to distribute marijuana and 
  possession with intent to distribute marijuana within one-half mile proximity 
  of a school.Â  
At trial, Abdullah moved to suppress 
  the evidence seized, contending that the search and seizure violated the Fourth 
  Amendment.Â  The circuit court granted the motion to suppress, concluding that 
  no exigent circumstances existed to justify the warrantless search.Â  The State 
  appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate 
  court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 
  5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  On appeal from a suppression hearing, this 
  court is bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings if any evidence supports 
  the findings.Â  State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 666 
  (2000).Â  In an appeal from a motion to suppress evidence based on Fourth Amendment 
  grounds, an appellate court may conduct its own review of the record to determine 
  whether the evidence supports the circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â  See State 
  v. Khingratsaiphon, 352 S.C. 62, 70, 572 S.E.2d 456, 460 (2002) (stating 
  â€œBrockman does not hold the appellate court may not conduct its own review 
  of the record to determine whether the trial judgeâ€™s decision is supported by 
  the evidenceâ€).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State argues that the circuit 
  court erred in granting Abdullahâ€™s motion to suppress evidence obtained during 
  its warrantless search of the apartment, contending the search did not violate 
  the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  We agree.
Through its â€œexclusionary rule,â€ 
  the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits unreasonable 
  searches and seizures.Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV.Â  Similarly, the South Carolina 
  Constitution provides protection against unlawful searches and seizures.Â  SeeÂ  
  S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10.Â  Evidence seized in violation of the Fourth Amendment 
  is excluded in both state and federal court.Â  See Mapp v. Ohio, 
  367 U.S. 643 (1961);Â  State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 643, 541 S.E.2d 
  837, 840 (2001).Â  
â€œGenerally, a warrantless search 
  is per se unreasonable and thus violative of the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s prohibition 
  against unreasonable searches and seizures.â€Â  State v. Bultron, 318 S.C. 
  323, 331, 457 S.E.2d 616, 621 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œHowever, a warrantless search 
  will withstand constitutional scrutiny where the search falls within one of 
  a few specifically established and well delineated exceptions to the Fourth 
  Amendment exclusionary rule.â€Â Â  Id., 317 S.C. at 331-32, 457 S.E.2d at 
  621.Â  In such cases, the burden is upon the State to justify a warrantless search.Â  
  State v. Bailey, 276 S.C. 32, 35, 274 S.E.2d 913, 915 (1981).Â  The State 
  contends that the warrantless search in the present case fell within exceptions 
  to the Fourth Amendment provided by the â€œexigent circumstances doctrineâ€ and 
  the â€œplain view doctrine.â€
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Exigent Circumstances
Law enforcement officials have long 
  been permitted to act without the permission of a magistrate when the â€œexigencies 
  of the situation [have] made that course imperative.â€Â  McDonald v. U.S., 
  335 U.S. 451, 456 (1948).Â  The exigent circumstances doctrine provides an exception 
  to the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s protection against warrantless searches, but only 
  where, from an objective standard, a â€œcompelling need for official action and 
  no time to secure a warrantâ€ exist.Â  State v. Brown, 289 S.C. 581, 587, 
  347 S.E.2d 882, 886 (1986) (quoting Michigan v. Tyler, 436 U.S. 499 (1978)).Â  
  For instance, a warrantless search is justified under the exigent circumstances 
  doctrine to prevent a suspect from fleeing or where there is a risk of danger 
  to police or others inside or outside a dwelling.Â  Minnesota v. Olson, 
  495 U.S. 91, 100 (1990).Â  In such circumstances, a protective sweep of the premises 
  may be permitted.Â  See Maryland v. Buie, 494 U.S. 325, 337 (1990) 
  (allowing a protective sweep of a house during an arrest where the officers 
  have â€œa reasonable belief based on specific and articulable facts that the area 
  to be swept harbors an individual posing a danger to those on the arrest sceneâ€);Â  
  see also Brown, 289 S.C. at 587, 347 S.E.2d at 886 (agreeing that 
  police may be justified in conducting a â€œprotective sweepâ€ of a crime scene 
  where the potential for danger exists).Â  Additionally, â€œthe Fourth Amendment 
  does not bar police officers from making warrantless entries and searches when 
  they reasonably believe that a person within is in need of immediate aid.â€Â  
  Mincey v. Arizona, 437 U.S. 385, 392 (1978). 
  [2] Â  
In the present case, the officers 
  were responding to a call reporting burglary and gunfire.Â  They arrived at the 
  scene to discover an uncooperative person, Abdullah, who only attempted to identify 
  himself as the alleged victim after the officers abandoned their reasonable 
  but futile efforts to secure his cooperation and instead turned to physically 
  subduing him.Â  Additionally, the officers observed bullet holes inside and outside 
  the walls of the premises.Â  We are firmly persuaded from our review of the record 
  that the totality of the circumstances, including Abdullahâ€™s unsettling behavior 
  and the evidence of a violent crime and gunfire, gave the officers highly reasonable 
  grounds from an objective standard for searching the premises with the dual 
  goals of securing the scene against perpetrators and facilitating assistance 
  to possible victims.Â  Moreover, the immediate need to secure the premises and 
  assist potential victims provided no time for the officers to obtain a warrant 
  before conducting their sweep of the crime scene.Â  Thus, we find the State met 
  its burden of proof in demonstrating that exigent circumstances existed to permit 
  the Stateâ€™s warrantless search of the premises where Abdullah and the drugs 
  were lawfully found.[3]
Accordingly, we find no evidence 
  in the record to support the circuit courtâ€™s assessment that, â€œonce [the officers] 
  handcuffed [Abdullah] to the chair, there werenâ€™t any exigent circumstances 
  anymore.â€Â  We find this basis for the circuit courtâ€™s ruling improvidently presupposes 
  that subduing and securing Abdullah foreclosed the officersâ€™ objectively reasonable 
  need to search the crime scene for suspects and victims. 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Plain View Doctrine [4] 
Under the plain view doctrine, any 
  object falling within the plain view of a law enforcement officer who is lawfully 
  in a position to view the object is subject to lawful seizure.Â  Brown, 
  289 S.C. at 588, 347 S.E.2d at 885.Â  The plain view exception to the warrant 
  requirement requires that â€œ(1) the initial intrusion which afforded the authorities 
  the plain view was lawful; (2) the discovery of the evidence was inadvertent; 
  and (3) the incriminating [nature of the] evidence was immediately apparent 
  to the seizing authorities.â€Â  State v. Culbreath, 300 S.C. 232, 237, 
  387 S.E.2d 255, 257 (1990). [5] 
Here, Officer Carrilloâ€™s initial 
  intrusion into the room containing the evidence was lawful because he was properly 
  conducting a protective sweep to secure the premises.Â  His discovery of the 
  gun, money and drugs was clearly inadvertent, because he was searching for other 
  victims or suspects and securing the scene.Â  Finally, Officer Carrillo testified 
  that the incriminating nature of the gun, money, and bags of marijuana was immediately 
  apparent to him.Â  Thus, we find that the items seized during the search, and 
  suppressed at trial, were clearly within Officer Carrilloâ€™s plain view.Â  Moreover, 
  we note that Abdullahâ€™s own attorney acknowledged before the circuit court that 
  the officers saw the drugs in â€œplain viewâ€ after they entered the house.
We respectfully find the circuit 
  courtâ€™s reliance on Arizona v. Hicks, 480 U.S. 321 (1987) to defeat the 
  Stateâ€™s plain view argument is misplaced.Â  In Hicks, the officer had 
  to move a stereo to read its serial number and identify it before he had probable 
  cause to seize it.Â  In contrast, Officer Carrillo had probable cause to seize 
  the evidence, without ever touching or moving it, because of his lawful presence 
  and immediate observations that the evidence was incriminating.Â  Thus, Hicks 
  is clearly distinguishable from the present case.
We also respectfully reject the circuit 
  courtâ€™s reasoning that turning on the bedroom light negated the application 
  of the plain view exception to the warrant requirement.Â  In Texas v. Brown, 
  460 U.S. 730 (1983), an officer shined a flashlight into a vehicle and saw contraband.Â  
  The United States Supreme Court held that the evidence was in plain view despite 
  the use of artificial illumination.Â  Id. at 740.Â  The Court stated that 
  â€œthe use of artificial means to illuminate a darkened area simply does not constitute 
  a search, and thus triggers no Fourth Amendment protection.â€Â  Id.Â  Similarly, 
  our supreme court in State v. Culbreath found that evidence was in plain 
  view, and subject to warrantless search and seizure, when an officer inadvertently 
  discovered the evidence by shining his flashlight into a suspectâ€™s car due to 
  legitimate concerns about the suspectâ€™s safety.Â  See also State 
  v. Daniels, 252 S.C. 591, 596, 167 S.E.2d 621, 624 (1969) (finding the use 
  of a flashlight in a lawful search of a suspectâ€™s car is â€œof no real consequenceâ€ 
  when the evidence found had been left in a place where it could be â€œeasily seenâ€).Â  
  Accordingly, we find Officer Carrilloâ€™s use of the bedroom light, particularly 
  under the exigent circumstances, was proper, and the evidence seized was in 
  plain view notwithstanding the use of artificial illumination.
CONCLUSION 

We conclude that the circuit court 
  erred in suppressing the evidence.Â  Due to the manifest presence of exigent 
  circumstances and the application of the plain view doctrine, the search did 
  not violate the Fourth Amendment and the evidence was properly seized.Â  The 
  circuit courtâ€™s decision is
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., and HOWARD, J., concur. 
  



 
   
    [1]    We review this interlocutory appeal under State v. McKnight, 
    287 S.C. 167, 168, 337 S.E.2d 208, 209 (1985) and State v. Henry, 313 
    S.C. 106, 108, 432 S.E.2d 489, 490 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Those cases provide, 
    in pertinent part, that â€œa pre-trial order granting the suppression of evidence 
    which significantly impairs the prosecution of a criminal case is directly 
    appealable under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(2)(a) (1976),â€ which permits appellate 
    review of â€œ[a]n order affecting a substantial right made in an action when 
    such order â€¦ in effect determines the action and prevents a judgment from 
    which an appeal might be taken or discontinues the action.â€Â  

 
   
    [2] In light of the uniformity and well-settled nature of exigent circumstances 
    law in federal and state courts throughout the United States, we elect not 
    to burden the reader with unnecessary case citations.Â  For the reader desiring 
    additional authority, we refer generally to 68 Am.Jur.2d Searches and Seizures 
    Â§ 134 (Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [3]    The reasonableness of the officersâ€™ conduct may be further gleaned 
    from the decision to secure a warrant to seize the contraband once the protective 
    sweep was concluded and exigent circumstances unquestionably ceased to exist.

 
   
    [4] Â We address the applicability of the plain view doctrine although 
    the evidence was technically seized pursuant to a warrant.Â  It is readily 
    apparent that the basis for the issuance of the warrant was Officer Carrilloâ€™s 
    plain view observation of the contraband.

 
   
    [5] However, the United States Supreme Court has concluded that the plain 
    view exception to the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s warrant requirement applies even 
    if the discovery of the evidence was not inadvertent, if the other requirements 
    of the exception are satisfied.Â  Horton v. California, 496 U.S. 128, 
    130 (1990).

title: Hinton v. S.C. Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services
description: This case involves the applicability of Sections 24-21-640 and 16-1-60 to out-of-state offenses so as to eliminate parole eligibility.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
       
        Jack L. Hinton, Jr., Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services, 
          Respondent. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
  Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master in Equity

Opinion No. 3722
  Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed January 12, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
       
        William M. Hagood, III, of Greenville, for Appellant
        Deputy Director for Legal Services Teresa A. Knox, Legal Counsel 
          Tommy Evans and Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, all of Columbia, for 
          Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Jack L. Hinton appeals from 
  a declaratory judgment that his out-of-state conviction rendered him ineligible 
  for parole by virtue of South Carolinaâ€™s subsequent violent offender statute.Â  
  We reverse.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND 
Since June 17, 1992, Jack L. Hinton has been serving 
  a thirty-year sentence pursuant to a South Carolina kidnapping conviction.Â  
  Prior to the present conviction, Appellant completed a jail sentence in Ohio 
  for a 1986 conviction for abduction.
Upon Appellantâ€™s incarceration, the South Carolina 
  Department of Corrections (â€œSCDCâ€) provided a projected parole eligibility date 
  of February 19, 2000.Â  Based on this projected date, the South Carolina Department 
  of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services (â€œthe Departmentâ€) conducted a pre-parole 
  investigation and presented Appellantâ€™s case to the Parole Board for a hearing 
  on March 1, 2000.Â  Appellant was denied parole shortly thereafter.
Before a second parole hearing scheduled for April 
  17, 2002, the Department notified Appellant that he was not eligible to be considered 
  for parole pursuant to South Carolinaâ€™s subsequent violent offender statute.
ISSUE

  For purposes of applying the subsequent violent offender provision of section 
    24-21-640, should the exclusive list of â€œviolent crimesâ€ in section 16-1-60 
    be interpreted to implicitly include out-of-state convictions?

LAW/ANALYSIS 
The Omnibus Crime Bill of June 3, 1986, enacted 
  section 16-1-60 and amended section 24-21-640 of the South Carolina Code to 
  prohibit the Parole Board from granting parole â€œto any prisoner serving a sentence 
  for a second or subsequent conviction, following a separate sentencing for a 
  prior conviction, for violent crimes as defined in Â§ 16-1-60.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 24-21-640 (Supp. 2001).Â  Section 16-1-60 codifies which crimes are considered 
  â€œviolent crimes.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-60 (Supp. 2001).Â  Effective January 
  1, 1994, the General Assembly amended section 16-1-60 so that each offenseâ€™s 
  name was parenthetically followed by its South Carolina Code section.Â  The statute 
  was again amended on January 12, 1995, this time adding the statuteâ€™s final 
  sentence:Â  â€œOnly those offenses specifically enumerated in this section are 
  considered violent offenses.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-60 (Supp. 2001).
South Carolina has long recognized the principle 
  that penal statutes are to be strictly construed.Â  State v. Germany, 
  216 S.C. 182, 188, 57 S.E.2d 165, 168 (1949) (â€œ[A] criminal statute must be 
  strictly construed against the State and any doubt must be resolved in favor 
  of the defendant . . . .â€); State v. Lewis, 141 S.C. 207, 211, 139 S.E. 
  386, 389 (1927) (â€œThis is a penal statute, and must be strictly construed.â€); 
  State v. Dupree, 354 S.C. 676, 693, 583 S.E.2d 437, 446 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (â€œPenal statutes are strictly construed against the State and in favor of the 
  defendant.â€).Â  At the same time, the cardinal rule of statutory construction 
  requires that we endeavor to â€œascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€Â  
  Branch v. City of Myrtle Beach, 340 S.C. 405, 409, 532 S.E.2d 289, 292 
  (2000); State v. Baucom, 340 S.C. 339, 531 S.E.2d 922 (2000); State 
  v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 365, 574 S.E.2d 203, 206 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  A law 
  must be interpreted reasonably and practically, consistent with the purpose 
  and policy of the General Assembly.Â  Abell v. Bell, 229 S.C. 1, 4, 91 
  S.E.2d 548, 550 (1956); see also Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, Inc. 
  v. County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 22, 579 S.E.2d 334, 336 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (â€œA statute should be given a reasonable and practical construction consistent 
  with the purpose and policy expressed in the statute.â€).
The terms must be construed in context and their 
  meaning determined by looking at the other terms used in the statute.Â  S. 
  Mut. Church Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Windstorm & Hail Underwriting Assâ€™n, 
  306 S.C. 339, 342, 412 S.E.2d 377, 379 (1991); Dupree, 354 S.C. at 693, 
  583 S.E.2d at 446.Â  Courts should consider not merely the language of the particular 
  clause being construed, but the word and its meaning in conjunction with the 
  purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  Whitner v. State, 
  328 S.C. 1, 16, 492 S.E.2d 777, 779 (1997); see also Stephen v. Avins 
  Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 340, 478 S.E.2d 74, 77 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding 
  statutory provisions should be given reasonable and practical construction consistent 
  with purpose and policy of entire act).Â  In interpreting a statute, the language 
  of the statute must be construed in a sense which harmonizes with its subject 
  matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. 
  Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992); Multi-Cinema, 
  Ltd. v. S.C. Tax Commâ€™n, 292 S.C. 411, 413, 357 S.E.2d 6, 7 (1987); State 
  v. Hudson, 336 S.C. 237, 246, 519 S.E.2d 577, 582 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Statutes 
  must be read as a whole and sections which are part of the same general statutory 
  scheme must be construed together and each given effect, if it can be done by 
  any reasonable construction.Â  Higgins v. State, 307 S.C. 446, 449, 415 
  S.E.2d 799, 801 (1992); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; see 
  also Abell, 229 S.C. at 5, 91 S.E.2d at 550 (â€œBut where the language 
  of the statute gives rise to doubt or uncertainty as to the legislative intent, 
  the search for that intent may range beyond the borders of the statute itself; 
  for it must be gathered from a reading of the statute as a whole in the light 
  of the circumstances and conditions existing at the time of its enactment.â€).
The legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained 
  primarily from the plain language of the statute.Â  Georgia-Carolina Bail 
  Bonds, 354 S.C. at 23, 579 S.E.2d at 336.Â  Words must be given their plain 
  and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction which 
  limits or expands the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Rowe v. Hyatt, 321 S.C. 366, 
  369, 468 S.E.2d 649, 650 (1996); City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 
  Blue Mazda Truck, 330 S.C. 371, 375, 498 S.E.2d 894, 898 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
  When faced with an undefined statutory term, the court must interpret the term 
  in accord with its usual and customary meaning.Â  Morgan, 352 S.C. at 
  366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Hudson, 336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 581.
If a statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, 
  and conveys a clear and definite meaning, there is no need to employ rules of 
  statutory interpretation and the court has no right to look for or impose another 
  meaning.Â  Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 436, 454 S.E.2d 
  890, 892 (1995); City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C. 556, 560, 486 S.E.2d 
  492, 494 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  When the terms of a statute are clear, the court 
  must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.Â  Cooper v. Moore, 
  351 S.C. 207, 212, 569 S.E.2d 330, 332 (2002); Holley v. Mount Vernon Mills, 
  Inc., 312 S.C. 320, 323, 440 S.E.2d 373, 374 (1994); Carolina Alliance 
  for Fair Employment v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 
  337 S.C. 476, 489, 523 S.E.2d 795, 802 (Ct. App. 1999); see also Parsons 
  v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 65, 456 S.E.2d 366, 367 (1995) (â€œWhere 
  the terms of a relevant statute are clear, there is no room for construction.â€).Â  
  However, if the language of an act gives rise to doubt or uncertainty as to 
  legislative intent, the construing court may search for that intent beyond the 
  borders of the act itself.Â  Morgan, 352 S.C. at 367, 574 S.E.2d at 207; 
  Hudson, 336 S.C. at 247, 519 S.E.2d at 582.Â Â  The statute as a whole 
  must receive practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with the 
  purpose, design, and policy of lawmakers.Â  Dupree, 354 S.C. at 694, 583 
  S.E.2d at 447; Brassell, 326 S.C. at 561, 486 S.E.2d at 495.Â  Any ambiguity 
  in a statute should be resolved in favor of a just, equitable, and beneficial 
  operation of the law.Â  City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t, 330 S.C. at 376, 
  498 S.E.2d at 896.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  On two occasions, the question of the 
  applicability of extra-jurisdictional criminal convictions to South Carolina 
  law has been reviewed, once by our supreme court and once by this court.Â  The 
  supreme court examined the issue in State v. Breech, 308 S.C. 356, 417 
  S.E.2d 873 (1992), which involved a defendant charged with unlawfully driving 
  under the influence of alcohol.Â  Specifically, the issue before the court was 
  whether the defendantâ€™s prior out-of-state convictions were within the scope 
  of section 56-5-2940, which enhanced the penalty for repeat offenders.Â  The 
  version of section 56-5-2940 in effect when the supreme court decided Breech 
  expounded:

  For the purposes of this chapter any conviction . . . for the violation of 
    any law or ordinance of this State or any municipality of this State that 
    prohibits any person from operating a motor vehicle while under the influence 
    of intoxicating liquor, drugs, or narcotics shall constitute a prior offense 
    for the purpose of any prosecution for any subsequent violation hereof.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2940 (1991).
Noting that the rules of statutory construction 
  required that criminal statutes be construed strictly with ambiguities resolved 
  in favor of the defendant, the supreme court determined that the statute did 
  not cover out-of-state convictions because explicit language in the statute 
  limited its coverage to â€œviolation of any law or ordinance of this State 
  or any municipality of this State.â€Â  Breech, 308 S.C. at 358, 
  417 S.E.2d at 874 (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2940 (1991)).Â  Effective June 
  30, 1992, the General Assembly subsequently amended section 56-5-2940 to provide 
  for enhanced penalties when the prior convictions were from another state: â€œFor 
  the purposes of this chapter any conviction, entry of a plea of guilty or of 
  nolo contendere, or forfeiture of bail for the violation of any law or ordinance 
  of this or any other state or any municipality of this or any other state that 
  prohibits a person from operating a motor vehicle while under the influence 
  of intoxicating liquor, drugs, or narcotics constitutes a prior offense for 
  the purpose of any prosecution for any subsequent violation hereof.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann Â§ 56-5-2940.Â  By virtue of the statutory amendment, the State is now permitted 
  to include out-of-state convictions in determining whether a DUI committed on 
  or after June 30, 1992 is a second or subsequent offense.Â  State v. Tennyson, 
  315 S.C. 471, 471-72, 445 S.E.2d 630, 630 (1994).
We recently addressed the same question for an entirely different statute in 
  State v. Zulfer, 345 S.C. 258, 547 S.E.2d 885 (Ct. App. 2001), cert. 
  dismissed, 353 S.C. 537, 579 S.E.2d 317 (2003).Â  Zulfer related to 
  section 16-11-311(A)(2), which allows a burglary offense to be enhanced to first-degree 
  burglary if â€œthe burglary is committed by a person with a prior record of two 
  or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a combination of both.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311(A)(2) (2003).
In concluding that the statute applied to out-of-state burglary and housebreaking 
  convictions, we stated that, unlike the â€œof this stateâ€ language in Breech, 
  the statute in Zulfer contained no language explicitly providing jurisdictional 
  limits.Â  We further noted that to â€œrestrict the predicate offenses for a first-degree 
  burglary charge to acts occurring within South Carolina would give the statute 
  a meaning that the legislature clearly did not intend.â€ State v. Zulfer, 
  345 S.C. 258, 263, 547 S.E.2d 885, 887 (Ct. App. 2001).
Other states have examined the use of prior convictions from another state 
  as the basis for the enhancement of punishment for an offense committed in the 
  forum state.Â  If the statute contains limiting language, the statute is determinative 
  of whether the prior out-of-state conviction may be utilized to enhance the 
  punishment.Â  The Supreme Court of New Hampshire held in New Hampshire v. 
  Cardin, 156 A.2d 118 (N.H. 1959) the defendant, who was charged with operating 
  a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquors, could not 
  be considered as a second offender when his first conviction was in Massachusetts.Â  
  Their statute reads:Â  

  Any person who shall be convicted of operating, or attempting to operate, 
    a motor vehicle upon any way while under the influence of intoxicating liquor 
    . . . shall be imprisoned . . . .Â  Upon a second conviction, he shall be imprisoned 
    . . . his license shall be revoked and he shall be ineligible for a license 
    for the next three calendar years.

Cardin, 156 A.2d at 315 (quoting N.H. Rev. 
  Stat. Ann. Â§ 262:19).Â  â€œWayâ€ is defined as â€œany public highway, street, avenue, 
  road, alley, park or parkway, or any private way laid out under authority of 
  statute.â€Â  Id.Â  The court professed:Â  â€œThe statute obviously refers to 
  a public way within the State of New Hampshire.Â  Whenever a conviction in another 
  state is to be considered in determining whether a second offense has been committed 
  under a local statute the Legislature has so stated in express terms.â€Â  Id.
In New Jersey v. Coleman, 484 A.2d 1250 (N.J. 1984), the Superior Court 
  of New Jersey, Appellate Division reviewed whether their mandatory extended 
  term of imprisonment for a person previously convicted of an offense involving 
  the use or possession of a firearm encompasses prior out-of-state convictions.Â  
  The statute declares:

  If the grounds specified in subsection d. are found . . . the court shall 
    sentence the defendant to an extended term as required by 2C:43-6c . . . . 
  

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

   d.       Second offender with a firearm.Â  
    The defendant is at least 18 years of age and has been previously convicted 
    of any of the following crimes: 2C:11-3, 2C:11-4, 2C:12-1b., 2C:13-1, 2C:14- 
    2a., 2C:14-3a., 2C:15-1, 2C:18-2, 2C:29-5, 2C:39-4a., or has been previously 
    convicted of an offense under Title 2A of the New Jersey Statutes which is 
    equivalent of the offenses enumerated in this subsection and he used or possessed 
    a firearm, as defined in 2C:39-1f., in the course of committing or attempting 
    to commit any of these crimes, including the immediate flight therefrom.

N.J. Stat. Ann. Â§ 2C:44-3.Â  N.J. Stat. Ann. section 2C:43-6c 
  provides:

  A person who has been convicted of an offense enumerated by this subsection 
    and who used or possessed a firearm during its commission, attempted commission 
    or flight therefrom and who has been previously convicted of an offense involving 
    the use or possession of a firearm as defined in 2C:44-3d., shall be sentenced 
    by the court to an extended term as authorized by 2C:43-7c., notwithstanding 
    that extended terms are ordinarily discretionary with the court.

The court held:

  [The defendant] was not â€œpreviously convicted of an offense involving the 
    use or possession of a firearm as defined in 2C:44-3d.â€Â  N.J.S.A. 2C:44-3d 
    is precise and unambiguous in its definition of the prior crimes which mandate 
    imposition of an extended term.Â  Certain Title 2C offenses are specified and 
    any other offense â€œunder Title 2A of the New Jersey Statutes which is equivalent 
    of the offenses enumerated in this subsection . . . .â€Â  No other offenses 
    are included; subsection d. does not allow equivalent offenses under the laws 
    of foreign jurisdictions to trigger the mandatory extended term provision.

Coleman, 484 A.2d at 1252.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In Missouri v. Rellihan, 662 S.W.2d 
  535 (Mo. Ct. App. 1983), the appellant argued the trial court erred in proclaiming 
  him to be a prior offender.Â  A prior offender is defined in their statute as 
  â€œone who has pleaded guilty to or has been found guilty of one felony.â€Â  Id. 
  at 543 (quoting Mo. Rev. Stat. Â§ 558.016.2).Â  The court ruled:

  The foregoing section (Â§ 558.016.2), by its very wording, sets forth no requirement 
    that the term felony is restricted or limited to felonies committed in Missouri.Â  
    To state it another way, it is clear to this court that the Missouri General 
    Assembly intended the term felony to define and thus include, felony offenses 
    from other jurisdictions--federal and sister states. . . .Â  The General Assembly, 
    had it intended otherwise, could have included limiting language, such as 
    â€œhas been found guilty of one felony in this state,â€ or words 
    of similar limitation.Â  No such language having been included by the General 
    Assembly, it is quite clear that the General Assembly intended the term felony 
    to be a term of inclusion which permits the trial court to impose sentencing, 
    instead of the jury, for a prior felony offense committed within, and subject 
    to, federal and sister state jurisdictions. 

Id. at 544-45.

  South Carolinaâ€™s subsequent violent offender statute establishes: 
  The board must not grant parole nor is parole authorized to any prisoner 
    serving a sentence for a second or subsequent conviction, following a separate 
    sentencing for a prior conviction, for violent crimes as defined in Section 
    16-1-60.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-640 (Supp. 2001).Â  Section 
  16-1-60, which was enacted concurrently in 1986, instructs: 

  For purposes of definition under South Carolina law, a violent crime includes 
    the offenses of . . . kidnapping (Section 16-3-910) . . . .Â  Only those offenses 
    specifically enumerated in this section are considered violent offenses.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-60 (Supp. 2001).
Contrastive to Breech where the legislature explicitly limited the statuteâ€™s 
  jurisdictional coverage, and dissimilar to Zulfer where the statute contained 
  no limits whatsoever, the statute in this case was amended in 1995 to include 
  its explicitly exclusionary ultimate sentence, but it is not clear whether or 
  not the General Assembly intended for that language to exclude convictions of 
  other jurisdictions.Â  In an informal opinion issued on May 24, 1995, an Assistant 
  Deputy Attorney General suggested that even after the January 12, 1995 amendment, 
  the statute encompasses crimes committed in other states or against federal 
  law, provided that the crime for which the offender was convicted shares the 
  same elements with one of the enumerated violent offenses of section 16-1-60.Â  
  S.C. Op. Atty. Gen. (1995 WL 803666). 
Although we do not think it sensible to place undue emphasis on statutory nomenclature 
  differences, we cannot discard as without import the glaring peculiarity that 
  the crime of abduction appears nowhere among the enumerated offenses of section 
  16-1-60.Â  The State urges the adoption of a same-elements test, which it contends 
  resolves this problem.Â  The Department explained that in following this approach, 
  it looks to whether the particular actions taken by the defendant which satisfy 
  the elements of the crime in the other state would satisfy the elements of one 
  of the enumerated crimes of section 16-1-60.
We find little evidence that such a test was the 
  intent of our legislature for this particular statute, for if it had been, such 
  an intent would have been made more overt, as is the case with section 17-25-45, 
  which was drafted to explicitly include â€œa federal or out-of-state conviction 
  for an offense that would be classified as a most serious offense under this 
  section.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (2000).
Moreover, we find such an approach unduly problematic, for we are uncertain 
  how the Parole Board could reliably know on which particular elements of an 
  offense a jury based its guilty verdict.Â  Indeed, as is the case with Ohioâ€™s 
  codification for abduction, there are multiple avenues by which a jury can determine 
  that an accused committed the crime of abduction.Â  The result is that, although 
  some abduction convictions may fit within the elements of South Carolinaâ€™s codification 
  of kidnapping, some abduction convictions invariably will not.Â  
Considering the relevant statutes in tandem illustrates 
  this disconcerting predicament.Â  Ohio has codified abduction as follows: 
 
  (A) No person, without privilege to do so, shall knowingly do any of the 
    following:
   
    (1) By force or threat, remove another from the place where the other person 
      is found;
    (2) By force or threat, restrain the liberty of another person, under circumstances 
      which create a risk of physical harm to the victim, or place the other person 
      in fear;
    (3) Hold another in a condition of involuntary servitude.
  
  (B) Whoever violates this section is guilty of abduction, a felony of the 
    third degree.

Ohio Rev. Code Ann. Â§ 2905.02 (West 2003).Â  South 
  Carolina has codified kidnapping as the following:

  Whoever shall unlawfully seize, confine, inveigle, decoy, kidnap, abduct 
    or carry away any other person by any means whatsoever without authority of 
    law, except when a minor is seized or taken by his parent, is guilty of a 
    felony and, upon conviction, must be imprisoned for a period not to exceed 
    thirty years unless sentenced for murder as provided in Section 16-3-20.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-910 (2003).
Based on one set of facts and circumstances, an 
  accused in Ohio may be prosecuted for abduction under several theoriesâ€”(1) the 
  accused â€œremove[d] another from the place where the other person is found,â€ 
  (2) the accused â€œrestrain[ed] the liberty of another personâ€ and still another 
  being that he â€œ[b]y force or threat, restrain[ed] the liberty of another person, 
  under circumstances which create a risk of physical harm to the victim, or place[d] 
  the other person in fear,â€ and (3) the accused â€œh[e]ld another in a condition 
  of involuntary servitude.â€Â  South Carolinaâ€™s kidnapping statute requires proof 
  of an unlawful act taking one of several alternative forms: seizure, confinement, 
  inveiglement, decoy, kidnapping, abduction, or carrying away.Â  State v. Bernsten, 
  259 S.C. 52, 54, 367 S.E.2d 152, 153 (1988); see State v. Owens, 
  291 S.C. 116, 118, 352 S.E.2d 474, 475 (1987).Â  â€œKidnaping is a continuing offense.â€Â  
  State v. Tucker, 334 S.C. 1, 13, 512 S.E.2d 99, 105 (1999); see 
  State v. Bennett, 328 S.C. 251, 264, 493 S.E.2d 845, 851.Â  â€œThe offense 
  commences when one is wrongfully deprived of freedom and continues until freedom 
  is restored.â€Â  State v. Hall, 280 S.C. 74, 78, 310 S.E.2d 429, 431 (1983) 
  (citing State v. Ziegler, 274 S.C. 6, 10, 260 S.E.2d 182, 184 (1979)).Â  
  â€œThe mens rea required for the crime of kidnapping . . . is â€˜knowledge.â€™â€Â  
  Tucker, 334 S.C. at 13, 512 S.E.2d at 105; see State v. Jefferies, 
  316 S.C. 13, 19, 446 S.E.2d 427, 430-31 (1994).
Given that no explication accompanies a juryâ€™s finding 
  of guilt, we are unclear how the Parole Board can differentiate which theory 
  the jury ultimately embraced--or alternatively stated, which elements the jury 
  found satisfied--in returning a guilty verdict.Â  Appellantâ€™s Ohio indictment 
  for kidnapping alleged that he

  without privilege to do so, knowingly and by force or threat, restrained 
    Anne Miller of her liberty, under circumstances which created a risk of physical 
    harm to the said Anne Miller or which place[d] the Anne Miller in fear, in 
    violation of section 2905.02 of the Ohio revised code and against the peace 
    and dignity of the state of Ohio.

Analyzing this indictment, we cannot say with any 
  degree of certitude whether the juryâ€™s guilty verdict was within the scope of 
  our kidnapping statute.Â  We find it unacceptable that the Parole Board should 
  look to the so-called â€œfactsâ€ of the case to make this determination, 
  for the â€œfactsâ€ are almost always disputed, and neither this court nor 
  the Parole Board has any way of extricating which particular â€œfactsâ€ the jury 
  decided were true and which were not.Â  The Parole Board should not undertake 
  such a determination in what would amount to a de facto second trial and an 
  egregious due process violation. 
Disavowing the same-elements test, the 1995 amendment to section 16-1-60, makes 
  plain that the General Assembly intended to prevent broadening of the statuteâ€™s 
  coverage.Â  We are unable to discern the intent of the General Assembly in regard 
  to the addition of the final sentence.Â  If we determine that the sentence was 
  meant only to prevent the expansion of â€œviolent crimesâ€ to other South Carolina 
  offenses not specifically enumerated in section 16-1-60, then we effectively 
  give the language no meaning because the principle of inclusio unius est 
  exclusio alterius (the inclusion of one is the exclusion of another) 
  already prohibits inclusion of non-enumerated offenses.Â  See Brown 
  v. State, 343 S.C. 342, 349, 540 S.E.2d 846, 850 (2001) (â€œThus, the maxim 
  of expressio unius est exclusio alterius . . . applies to exclude day 
  care centers from falling within the statute since day care centers are not 
  expressly included.â€).Â  Such an interpretation violates the rule that we should 
  seek a construction that gives effect to every word of a statute rather than 
  adopting an interpretation that renders a portion meaningless.Â  See McClenaghan 
  v. McClenaghan, 20 S.C. Eq. (1 Strob. Eq.) 295 (1847) (observing â€œif the 
  clause means any thing, and we are obliged to find some meaning for it, on the 
  maxim ut res magis valeat quam pereatâ€). 
In enacting the 1995 amendment, the General Assembly intended to circumscribe 
  application of the statute.Â  Because we cannot judicially fashion a demarcation 
  line, we are bound to construe the statute with exactitude.Â  First, when the 
  nature of restrictive language is irresolvedly ambiguous, prudence dictates 
  that we adopt the interpretation least likely to run afoul of the legislatureâ€™s 
  restrictive intent.Â  In this case, that interpretation is one of strict construction.Â  
  Second, in applying such an interpretation, our practice remains in accord with 
  the requirement that penal statutes be construed strictly against the State.Â  
  Third, by adopting such an interpretation of section 16-1-60, we avoid the needless 
  entanglement of a same-elements test.
Finally, we note that our decision does not mean that Appellant will ever succeed 
  in being paroled.Â  Instead, our ruling merely assures that the authority to 
  grant or deny parole remains with the body that can most capably make such challenging, 
  case-by-case determinations:Â  the Parole Board.
REVERSED.
CURETON, A.J., concurs.
GOOLSBY, J., concurs in a separate opinion.
GOOLSBY, J. (concurring in result): I concur 
  in the result reached by the majority, that an Ohio conviction for the crime 
  of abduction does not qualify as a second or subsequent conviction under S.C. 
  Code Ann. ' 24-21-640 (Supp. 2002), a statute that prohibits the Board of South 
  Carolina Probation, Parole and Pardon Services from granting a parole to a â€œprisoner 
  serving a second or subsequent conviction . . . for violent crimes as defined 
  in Section 16-1-60.â€Â  I simply differ with the majority in how we should arrive 
  at that conclusion.
The respondent Jack L. Hinton, a prisoner serving a sentence for kidnapping 
  since his conviction in 1992 in Greenville County, South Carolina, once served 
  a sentence of from three to ten years following his conviction in 1986 in Hamilton 
  County, Ohio, for the offense of abduction, an offense proscribed by Ohio Rev. 
  Code Ann. ' 2905.02 (2002). 
Section 24-21-640 provides in part as follows:

  The board must not grant parole nor is parole authorized to any prisoner 
    serving a sentence for a second or subsequent conviction, following a separate 
    sentencing for a prior conviction, for violent crimes as defined in Section 
    16-1-60.

At the time of his conviction in South Carolina 
  in 1992, S.C. Code Ann. ' 16-1-60 (1991), [1]  provided in relevant part:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  


  For purposes of definition under South Carolina law, a violent crime includes 
    the offenses of . . . kidnapping . . . . 

A related statute, S.C. Code Ann. ' 16-1-70 (1991), defined a â€œnonviolent crimeâ€ 
  as including â€œall offenses not specifically enumerated in Section 16-1-60.â€

Subsequent amendments to Section 16-1-60, 
  [2]  among other things,Â  added code sections to identify the offenses defined 
  as violent crimes and a second sentence which reads, â€œOnly those offenses specifically 
  enumerated in this section are considered violent offenses.â€
Because Section 16-1-60 is a penal statute, its 
  terms must be strictly construed against the State and in favor of the defendant. 
  [3] Â  We, as judges, can add nothing to the words of the statute either 
  by inference or intendment but must construe those words literally. 
  [4] 
At no point in its history has Section 16-1-60 
  defined the offense of abduction in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ' 2905.02 
  (2002) as a violent crime.Â  That offense throughout has not been one â€œspecifically 
  enumerated in Section 16-1-60.â€Â  According a strict construction to Section 
  16-1-60 and a liberal construction to Section 16-1-70, we can only conclude 
  that the term â€œviolent crime,â€ as used in Section 16-1-60 does not include the 
  offense of abduction in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ' 2905.02 (2002).
This court's decision in State v. Zulfer, [5]  a case that dealt with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311(A)(2) 
  (Supp. 2000), does not aid the State. The wording that statute employs differs 
  considerably from that of Section 16-1-60.Â  


 
   [1] 
    Â  See Act No. 184, 1993 S.C. Acts 3239.

 
   [2] 
     See Act No. 7, 1995 S.C. Acts 50; Act No. 83, 1995 S.C. Acts 556; 
    Act No. 113, 1997 S.C. Acts 524; Act No. 136, 1997 S.C. Acts 688; Act No. 
    402, 1998 S.C. Acts 2450; Act No. 261, 2000 S.C. Acts 1929.

 
   [3] 
     State v. Cutler, 274 S.C. 376, 378, 264 S.E.2d 420, 420-21 (1980).

 
   [4] 
     State v. Lewis, 141 S.C. 207, 220-21, 139 S.E.2d 386, 391 (1927).

 
   [5] 
     345 S.C. 258, 547 S.E.2d 885 (Ct. App. 2001), cert. dismissed, 
    353 S.C. 537, 579 S.E.2d 317 (2003).
