description: CEL filed a complaint against Rozelle and Rozelle counterclaimed. Rozelle appeals the trial judge's order granting summary judgment on her counterclaims. We affirm.
text:
CEL v. Rozelle


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
       
        CEL Products, LLC, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Margaret F. Rozelle, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3723
  Submitted October 6, 2003 â€“ Filed January 12, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Chalmers C. Johnson, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Sean K. Trundy, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.: CEL Products, LLC (â€œCELâ€) filed 
  a complaint against Margaret Rozelle (â€œRozelleâ€) alleging numerous actions.Â  
  Rozelle counterclaimed. Rozelle appeals the trial judgeâ€™s order granting summary 
  judgment on Rozelleâ€™s counterclaims.Â  We affirm.

  FACTS
  CEL purchased a business from William and Joanna White (â€œthe 
    Whitesâ€). After taking over the business, CEL kept Rozelle, who had worked 
    for the Whites, as an at-will employee. CEL later became dissatisfied with 
    Rozelle and fired her. CEL eventually brought suit against the Whites, claiming 
    fraud in the sale of the business. The circuit court ordered the Whitesâ€™ accounts 
    receivable to be held in escrow. According to CEL, Rozelle then induced several 
    customers owing those accounts receivable to make payments into a non-escrow 
    account. 

On October 27, 2000, CEL filed a complaint against Rozelle alleging civil contempt, 
tortious interference with contract, conspiracy, and unfair trade practices. In 
February 2001, Rozelle answered and counterclaimed, claiming abuse of process, 
libel and slander, and intentional infliction of emotional distress. She also 
alleged that CELâ€™s suit was frivolous under S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-36-10 to -50 
(Supp. 2000), the Frivolous Proceedings Sanctions Act. Rozelle served interrogatories, 
requests for admission, and requests for production on CEL, at the same time as 
her answer. CEL failed to respond, and Rozelle moved to compel in June 2001. The 
trial court granted Rozelleâ€™s motion to compel on December 6, 2001. Around that 
time, CEL moved for a voluntary dismissal of its action against Rozelle and for 
summary judgment on Rozelleâ€™s counterclaims. CEL submitted responses to Rozelleâ€™s 
interrogatories and requests for production on December 17, 2001. 
In March and April 2002, Rozelle attempted to depose Charles Lee, but the parties 
  failed to reach an agreement on scheduling so the deposition did not take place. 
  Rozelle filed a new motion to compel the deposition on April 14. In July of 
  2003, the trial judge held a hearing to entertain the various motions. The judge 
  first granted CELâ€™s motion for voluntary dismissal of CELâ€™s actions. Then, the 
  judge granted CELâ€™s motion for summary judgment as to Rozelleâ€™s counterclaims. 
  The trial judge did not rule on Rozelleâ€™s motion to compel.
ISSUES

  
    (1) 
     
      Did the trial court err in granting summary judgment since 
        Rozelle claims not to have had a full and fair opportunity to conduct 
        discovery?
    
  
  
    (2) 
    Did the trial court err in hearing the motion to dismiss before 
      hearing the motion to compel discovery?
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate where there is 
  no genuine issue of material fact and it is clear the moving party is entitled 
  to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  However, summary judgment 
  is improper if the parties dispute the inferences to be drawn from the facts 
  even if the facts themselves are not in dispute. Tupper v. Dorchester County, 
  326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  â€œIn determining whether any 
  triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Osborne 
  ex rel. Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS 
Rozelle argues the trial judge erred in granting CELâ€™s 
  motion for summary judgment on her counterclaims because she had not been afforded 
  a â€œfull and fair opportunityâ€ to complete discovery.Â  Rozelle further argues 
  the trial judge should have conducted a hearing on her motion to compel a deposition 
  before granting the motion for summary judgment. We disagree.
â€œThe plain language of Rule 56(c), SCRCP, mandates 
  the entry of summary judgment, after adequate time for discovery against a party 
  who fails to make a showing sufficient to establish the existence of an element 
  essential to the partyâ€™s case and on which that party will bear the burden of 
  proof at trial.â€ Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment v. S.C. Dept. of Labor, 
  Licensing, and Regulation, 337 S.C. 476, 485, 523 S.E.2d 795, 800 (Ct. App. 
  1999).
The hearing on CELâ€™s motion for summary judgment 
  occurred seventeen months after Rozelle filed her answer and counterclaims. [1] Â  Rozelle did not attempt to schedule a deposition 
  until thirteen months after filing her counterclaims. More importantly, Rozelle 
  did not present an affidavit in response to CELâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  
  As a result, the trial judge had only Rozelleâ€™s pleadings and CELâ€™s affidavits 
  before him. Therefore, he did not err in granting the motion for summary judgment.Â  
  See Humana Hosp.-Bayside v. Lightle, 305 S.C. 214, 216, 407 S.E.2d 
  637, 638 (1991) (â€œWhere a plaintiff relies solely upon the pleadings, files 
  no counter-affidavits, and makes no factual showing in opposition to a motion 
  for summary judgment, the lower court is required, under Rule 56, to grant summary 
  judgment, if, under the facts presented by the defendant, he was entitled to 
  judgment as a matter of law.â€). 
Nor was it error for the trial judge to grant CELâ€™s motion for summary judgment 
  before conducting a hearing on Rozelleâ€™s motion to compel discovery.Â  The manner 
  in which a trial is conducted is within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion.Â  See, 
  e.g., Baber v. Greenville County, 327 S.C. 31, 41, 488 S.E.2d 
  314, 319 (1997) (holding that the conduct of a trial is largely within the trial 
  judgeâ€™s sound discretion, the exercise of which will not be disturbed on appeal 
  absent an abuse of that discretion or the commission of a legal error that results 
  in prejudice for appellant).Â  Had the trial judge granted CELâ€™s summary judgment 
  motion prior to considering the prejudice to Rozell caused by the inability 
  to depose Lee, the trial judge would have failed to exercise discretion.Â  A 
  failure to exercise discretion amounts to an abuse of that discretion.Â  Samples 
  v. Mitchell, 329 S.C. 105,112, 495 S.E.2d 213, 216 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  When 
  a trial judge is vested with discretion but his ruling reveals no discretion 
  was in fact exercised, an error of law has occurred.Â  Ballon Plantation, 
  Inc. v. Head Balloons, Inc., 303 S.C. 152,155, 399 S.E.2d 439, 441 (1990).Â  

In the instant case it is clear from the record that the trial court exercised 
  discretion.Â  The following colloquy took place:
 
  
    THE COURT:Â Â Â Â Â Â  Where is the affidavit that is submitted in response to 
      his motion for summary judgment?
    MS. TRAVAGLIO:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We have not submitted any affidavits in response 
      to his motion.
    THE COURT:Â Â Â Â Â Â  How do I make a determination then that there is an issue 
      of fact in this case?Â  Based on what?Â  What do I have?â€¦
    THE COURT:Â Â Â Â Â Â  My question is when you file a lawsuit, surely you arenâ€™t 
      filing a lawsuit thinking, I think I have a cause of action.
    THE COURT:Â Â Â Â Â Â  You have a cause of action and itâ€™s based on something 
      that you have.
    MS. TRAVAGLIO:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Yes, Your Honor.
    THE COURT:Â Â Â Â Â Â  Now, you strengthen that through discovery, but you donâ€™t 
      create your cause of action by taking depositions.Â Â Â Â Â  
  

Rozelleâ€™s response to CELâ€™s summary judgment motion and 
  affidavits was a request for a continuance to depose Lee, but Rozelle failed 
  to demonstrate that further discovery would be beneficial.Â  See Dawkins 
  v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 439 (2003) (stating â€œnon moving 
  party to summary judgment motion must demonstrate the likelihood that further 
  discovery will uncover additional relevant evidence and that the party is not 
  merely engaged in a fishing expeditionâ€).
This court is cognizant of the Supreme Courtâ€™s decision 
  in Lanham v. Blue Cross, 349 S.C. 356, 563 S.E.2d. 331 (2002).Â  In Lanham, 
  the court found that the trial court erred in ruling on the summary judgment 
  motion without first ruling on Lanhamâ€™s motion to produce and motion to compel. 
  However, the instant case is distinguishable from Lanham.Â  In Lanham, 
  the information sought in discovery was necessary to respond to a material claim 
  by Blue Cross and the information was in the sole possession of 
  Blue Cross.Â  That is not the case here.Â  Rozelleâ€™s counterclaims were centered 
  on alleged statements made by, and to, CELâ€™s owner, Lee.Â  CEL had disclosed 
  what those statements were, who made them and to whom they were made.Â  Rozelle 
  failed to offer anything that contradicted this.Â  Deposing Lee would have yielded 
  very little, if any, additional relevant evidence.Â  As the instant case was 
  approximately twenty-one months old when CEL filed its motion for summary judgment, 
  Rozelleâ€™s ability to sustain her counterclaims should not have hinged upon speculative 
  deposition evidence.Â  As such, summary judgment was warranted to avoid prolonging 
  litigation based upon a mere possibility that Rozelle might obtain some helpful 
  information from a deposition.
â€œThe gist and gravamen of the discovery rules mandate full 
  and fair disclosure to prevent a trial from becoming a guessing game or one 
  of ambush for either party.â€Â  Scott v. Greenville Hous. Auth., 353 S.C. 
  639, 652, 579 S.E.2d 151, 158 (Ct. App. 2003). â€œThe rights of discovery provided 
  by the Rules give the trial lawyer the means to be prepared for trial. Where 
  these rights are not accorded, prejudice must be presumed and, unless the party 
  who has failed to submit to discovery can show a lack of prejudice, reversal 
  is required.â€ Downy v. Dixon 294 S.C. 42, 46, 362 S.E.2d 317, 319 (Ct. 
  App. 1987).Â  Here, CEL showed and the record indicates that Rozelle suffered 
  no prejudice.
CONCLUSION 
Based upon the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
GOOLSBY and HUFF, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  While we affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling, the 
    procedural history of this case raises a concern. The record makes very clear 
    that CEL did not cooperate with Rozelleâ€™s discovery requests.Â  Rozelle served 
    interrogatories, requests to admit, and requests for production upon CEL in 
    February 2001, but CEL did not respond.Â  Rozelle then filed a motion to compel 
    in June 2001.Â  CEL did not complete this discovery until December 2001, when 
    the trial judge issued an order compelling it to respond.Â  In failing to respond 
    to Rozelleâ€™s discovery for approximately ten months â€“ including six months 
    after Rozelle filed the motion to compel â€“ CEL significantly delayed the resolution 
    of this case.Â  We do not condone such dilatory tactics.

title: State v. Pagan
description: This criminal appeal alleges error in the Circuit Judge's admission of evidence involving flight and guilty conscience as well as corroborative testimony about the commission of a murder and threats to a witness.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA



THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals


 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Charles Pagan, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence 
  County
  L. Casey Manning, Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3724
  Heard December 9, 2003 
  â€“ Filed January 12, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Deputy Chief Attorney 
          Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry 
          Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
          Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka and Assistant Attorney General 
          S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar L. Clements, 
          III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Charles Pagan 
  was convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  Pagan appeals, 
  arguing the trial judge erred in allowing testimony from an individual about 
  an incident that occurred more than one year after the victimâ€™s murder.Â  We 
  affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL 
  BACKGROUND 
At approximately 8:00 a.m. on December 
  11, 1997, the victimâ€™s body was discovered in a vacant lot in Florence, South 
  Carolina.Â  DNA testing revealed there was semen on the victimâ€™s pants and in 
  her vagina.Â  Dr. Edward Proctor, the forensic pathologist who performed the 
  autopsy, concluded the victim died as a result of â€œmassive blunt force injury 
  to the head,â€ likely caused by multiple blows from a heavy object, such as a 
  board.Â  
Steven 
  [1]  Blathers, an acquaintance of the victim, lived across the street from 
  the vacant lot where the body was found.Â  After DNA testing, it was determined 
  that the semen found on the victim belonged to Blathers.Â  Blathers admitted 
  to having sex with the victim in exchange for providing her with crack cocaine.Â  
  However, Blathers was not viewed as a suspect because his mother attested he 
  was home at the approximate time the victim was attacked.Â  Additionally, Jessie 
  Jones, a neighbor of Blathers who lived in front of the vacant lot, saw the 
  victim fighting with a man that night and testified Blathers did not match the 
  description of that individual.Â  The following colloquy occurred during direct 
  examination of Jones:

  Q.Â  How tall is Mr. Steve Blathers?
  A.Â  About five foot if he that.Â  
    He was short.
  Q.Â  You didnâ€™t see Steve Blathers 
    out there by that school bus at the fight, didnâ€™t you?
  A.Â  Not that I can say for sure, 
    no.
  Q.Â  Well, that fellow you described 
    is six feet light-skinned wasnâ€™t Steve Blathers?
  A.Â  No.
  Q.Â  And you didnâ€™t see Steve Blathers 
    around there, didnâ€™t you?
  A.Â  No, I didnâ€™t.Â  Because I couldnâ€™t 
    recognize none of them.

Jones stated 
  that, around 2:00 a.m. the morning of the murder, he observed a group of people 
  hitting a sign with a stick outside of his house.Â  Thereafter, Jones noticed 
  a â€œtall manâ€ and a â€œlady [who] was kind of shortâ€ arguing and â€œhitting each 
  other with sticks.â€Â  Another neighbor, Patrice Washington, said that, at approximately 
  2:10 a.m., she witnessed a â€œshadow run pas[t] [her] window,â€ followed by â€œtwo 
  more shadows.â€Â  Washington declared â€œ[t]he first shadow was screaming.â€Â  Sometime 
  after 2:00 a.m., Blathers looked out the door of his house and saw a six-foot 
  tall â€œshadow run across the streetâ€ with â€œsomething in [his] hand.â€
Monique Ellerbee Cooks 
  [2]  called Crime Stoppers the night the victimâ€™s body was discovered.Â  
  Cooks informed Crime Stoppers that she was with the victim at a club on the 
  night of the murder.Â  Cooks claimed the victim left the club with a man and 
  that Cooks did not see the victim again.Â  Cooks gave a detailed description 
  of the man.Â  When police visited Cooks, she reiterated that she had been with 
  the victim the night she was killed but did not tell the police that she had 
  witnessed the murder.Â  Cooks failed to point out anyone in three photographic 
  lineups, one of which included Pagan.
Cooks later assisted police in drawing 
  a composite sketch of the man she saw with the victim the night of the murder.Â  
  Police interviewed Pagan after an individual identified him from the composite 
  sketch.Â  Police then re-interviewed Cooks, who identified Pagan in a photographic 
  lineup as the person she saw with the victim the night of the murder.Â  Cooks 
  indicated that she had recognized Pagan the first time she viewed the lineup 
  but that â€œshe was scared to point him outâ€ at that time.
Approximately one month later, Cooks 
  professed that she witnessed the murder.Â  On the night the victim was killed, 
  Cooks followed the victim, who was walking with a man that Cooks had never seen 
  before.Â  Cooks heard the victim arguing with the man about money and drugs.Â  
  Speaking in an angry tone, the man asked the victim for the twenty dollars she 
  owed him.Â  While standing in the area where Jessie Jones stated he had seen 
  people hitting a sign, Cooks watched the man and victim â€œhitting each other 
  with sticks.â€Â  The man told the victim, â€œBitch, you gone give me my money.â€Â Â Â  
  When the victim ran, the man chased the victim and beat her in the face and 
  head with a board.Â  Cooks screamed.Â  The man told Cooks that he was going to 
  â€œget [her] next.â€Â  Cooks identified Pagan as the victimâ€™s attacker.
Police issued an arrest warrant for 
  Pagan on January 15, 1998.Â  Pagan fled to New Jersey but was apprehended on 
  February 20, 1998.
In February 1999, more than one year 
  after the murder, Pagan was arrested while out on bond.Â  The arrest was based 
  upon a statement given by Tamika Lambert.Â  Lambert stated she was the passenger 
  in a vehicle being driven by someone named â€œDerrickâ€ when a police car with 
  its blue light on attempted to pull them over.Â  According to Lambert, â€œDerrickâ€ 
  drove off at a high speed, crashed the car, and ran away.Â  When Lambert saw 
  â€œDerrickâ€ several hours later, â€œDerrickâ€ apologized to her and explained why 
  he ran from the police.Â  Lambert declared:

  He start[ed] out telling me that 
    he couldnâ€™t stop because he didnâ€™t have no [driverâ€™s] license.Â  Then he told 
    me that he was onâ€”Iâ€™m trying to see which one he told me first.Â  He was on 
    a $100,000 bond because they hadâ€”[t]his girlâ€”[t]hey accused him of killing 
    some girl.Â  And it was all because of some girl named Monica.

Lambert identified Pagan as the man 
  who (1) told her his name was â€œDerrickâ€; (2) ran from the police; (3) wrecked 
  the car; and (4) later explained to her why he had run from the police.Â  The 
  car that Pagan wrecked after the chase was registered to Paganâ€™s wife.Â  Pagan 
  denied both knowing Lambert and wrecking his wifeâ€™s car.
Before Lambert testified at trial, 
  defense counsel objected to her testimony, claiming the evidence was unduly 
  prejudicial and too remote in time to be considered in conjunction with the 
  murder charge.Â  The trial court overruled the objection, finding Lambertâ€™s testimony 
  was admissible under Rule 404(b), SCRE, as Monique Ellerbee Cooks said sheâ€™d 
  been threatened and Lambertâ€™s testimony referred to Paganâ€™s comment that a girl 
  named â€œMonicaâ€ was the cause of his problems.Â  Defense counsel unsuccessfully 
  renewed this objection after Lambert testified.Â  In charging the jury, the trial 
  judge instructed that Lambertâ€™s testimony was admissible only as to identification.
The jury found Pagan guilty of murder.Â  
  He was sentenced to life imprisonment.
LAW/ANALYSIS 

Pagan contends the trial judge erred 
  in admitting Tamika Lambertâ€™s testimony.Â  Specifically, Pagan claims Lambertâ€™s 
  testimony that Pagan ran from police while out on bond for this murder charge 
  was only slightly relevant, yet highly prejudicial.Â  We disagree.
I.Â  Evidence of Flight 
â€œFlight from prosecution is admissible 
  as evidence of guilt.â€Â  State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 413, 578 S.E.2d 
  32, 36-37 (Ct. App. 2003); see also State v. Ballenger, 322 S.C. 
  196, 200, 470 S.E.2d 851, 854 (1996) (stating flight is â€œat least some evidenceâ€ 
  of defendantâ€™s guilt); State v. Freely, 105 S.C. 243, 89 S.E. 643 (1916) 
  (declaring the flight of one charged with crime has always been held to be some 
  evidence tending to prove guilt).Â  Evidence of flight has been held to constitute 
  evidence of defendantâ€™s guilty knowledge and intent.Â  See State v. 
  Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 513 S.E.2d 606 (1999); Town of Hartsville v. Munger, 
  93 S.C. 527, 77 S.E. 219 (1913); State v. Brownlee, 318 S.C. 34, 455 
  S.E.2d 704 (Ct. App. 1995); see also State v. Thompson, 278 S.C. 
  1, 292 S.E.2d 581 (1982), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 
  305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (finding evidence of flight admissible to 
  show guilty knowledge, intent, and that defendant sought to avoid apprehension); 
  State v. Grant, 275 S.C. 404, 407, 272 S.E.2d 169, 171 (1980) (â€œ[A]ttempts 
  to run away have always been regarded as some evidence of guilty knowledge and 
  intent.â€) (internal quotation marks omitted); State v. Davis, 354 S.C. 
  348, 580 S.E.2d 778 (Ct. App. 2003) (noting that circumstances of defendantâ€™s 
  flight from police after they attempted traffic stop allowed reasonable inference 
  of guilty conduct).Â  Flight, when unexplained, is admissible as indicating consciousness 
  of guilt, for it is not to be supposed that one who is innocent and conscious 
  of that fact would flee.Â  See State v. Williams, 350 S.C. 172, 
  564 S.E.2d 688 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing 29 Am. Jur. 2d Evidence Â§ 532 
  (1994)).
The critical factor to the admissibility 
  of evidence of flight is whether the totality of the evidence creates an inference 
  that the defendant had knowledge that he was being sought by the authorities.Â  
  Beckham, 334 S.C. at 315, 513 S.E.2d at 612.Â  It is sufficient that circumstances 
  justify an inference that the accusedâ€™s actions were motivated as a result of 
  his belief that police officers were aware of his wrongdoing and were seeking 
  him for that purpose.Â  Id. (citing Commonwealth v. Jones, 319 
  A.2d 142 (Pa. 1974)).Â  Flight or evasion of arrest is a circumstance to go to 
  the jury.Â  See Beckham, 334 S.C. at 315, 513 S.E.2d at 612; State 
  v. Turnage, 107 S.C. 478, 93 S.E. 182 (1917); see also State v. 
  Byers, 277 S.C. 176, 284 S.E.2d 360 (1981) (recognizing that evidence of 
  flight is proper and that it is oftentimes appropriate for counsel to argue 
  to the jury the inferences growing out of flight); Grant, 275 S.C. at 
  408, 272 S.E.2d at 171 (stating that while a jury charge on flight as evidence 
  of guilt is improper, admission of evidence and argument by counsel concerning 
  it are allowed).
Tamika Lambertâ€™s testimony was clearly 
  admissible for the purposes of proving Paganâ€™s flight and â€œguilty knowledge.â€Â  
  After failing to stop for a blue light, evading police, and leaving the scene 
  of the accident, Pagan told Lambert he was out on bond â€œbecause they . . . accused 
  him of killing some girl,â€ and that he was in trouble because of a girl named 
  â€œMonica.â€Â  As such, Lambertâ€™s testimony was admissible for proving: (1) Pagan 
  was attempting to avoid capture and violate his bond provisions for the murder 
  charged in the instant case and (2) Pagan could identify the very person, Monique 
  Ellerbee Cooks, who was the key witness in the case.Â  A jury could have easily 
  inferred knowledge of Paganâ€™s guilt from these actions.
In State v. Beckham, the defendant 
  left for a vacation in Florida several hours before a warrant was issued for 
  his arrest.Â  After spending one hour in a Florida hotel, defendant then drove 
  all night to Kentucky.Â  Our Supreme Court held this was admissible as flight 
  evidence and was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Beckham, 334 S.C. at 
  315, 513 S.E.2d at 612-13.Â  Similarly, in State v. Al-Amin, the defendant 
  fled the scene after dumping the victimâ€™s body in a dumpster next to his apartment.Â  
  This Court found evidence of the defendantâ€™s flight was circumstantial evidence 
  to be submitted to the jury.Â  Al-Amin, 353 S.C. at 413, 578 S.E.2d at 
  36-37.Â  
Pagan cites McFadden v. State, 
  342 S.C. 637, 539 S.E.2d 391 (2000), in his brief for the proposition that Tamika 
  Lambertâ€™s testimony was not admissible as evidence of flight because the police 
  were â€œnot at that point pursuing [Pagan] as a suspect in the earlier murder.â€Â  
  However, McFadden is clearly inapposite as it concerns the rule that, 
  in a trial in absentia, the jury cannot consider the defendantâ€™s 
  absence at trial as evidence of defendantâ€™s guilt.Â  McFadden, 342 S.C. 
  at 644-45, 539 S.E.2d at 395.
Concomitantly, we find Tamika Lambertâ€™s 
  testimony was properly admitted as flight or â€œguilty knowledgeâ€ evidence.
II.Â  Corroboration 
  Evidence 
All relevant evidence is admissible.Â  
  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 551 S.E.2d 240 (2001); State v. Aleksey, 
  343 S.C. 20, 538 S.E.2d 248 (2000); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 
  S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003); Rule 402, SCRE.Â  â€œRelevant evidenceâ€ is defined 
  as evidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of 
  consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable 
  than it would be without the evidence.Â  State v. Shuler, 353 S.C. 176, 
  577 S.E.2d 438 (2003); State v. Braxton, 343 S.C. 629, 541 S.E.2d 833 
  (2001); State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 543 S.E.2d 586 (Ct. App. 2001); 
  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  Under Rule 401, evidence is relevant if it has a direct bearing 
  upon and tends to establish or make more or less probable the matter in controversy.Â  
  In re Corley, 353 S.C. 202, 577 S.E.2d 451 (2003); Adams, 354 
  S.C. at 378, 580 S.E.2d at 794; State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 561 S.E.2d 
  640 (Ct. App. 2002).
As the only eyewitness able to identify 
  Pagan as the victimâ€™s killer, Monique Ellerbee Cooksâ€™s credibility was of utmost 
  importance.Â  Cooks was not entirely forthcoming in her first few meetings with 
  investigators, which might have adversely affected the veracity of her testimony.Â  
  We find Lambertâ€™s testimony about Paganâ€™s comments after he fled from police 
  was relevant in corroborating Cooksâ€™s testimony.Â  Lambert declared that Pagan 
  told her he was out on bond â€œbecause they . . . accused him of killing some 
  girl,â€ and he blamed this trouble on someone named â€œMonica.â€Â  This corroborates 
  Cooksâ€™s testimony in two respects: (1) that she was an eyewitness to the crime 
  and (2) that Pagan knew her identity.Â  Similarly, Lambertâ€™s testimony corroborates 
  Cooksâ€™s statement that she was afraid of Pagan, and that he said he would â€œget 
  [her] next.â€
Consequently, Tamika Lambertâ€™s testimony 
  was properly admitted as corroboration evidence, as it supported Cooksâ€™s testimony.
III.Â  
  Identity Under Rule 404(b)
Generally, South Carolina law precludes 
  evidence of a defendantâ€™s prior crimes or other bad acts to prove the defendantâ€™s 
  guilt for the crime charged.Â  State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. 460, 523 
  S.E.2d 787 (Ct. App. 1999); see also State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 
  536 S.E.2d 679 (2000) (finding that evidence of prior crimes or bad acts is 
  inadmissible to prove bad character of defendant or that he acted in conformity 
  therewith).Â  Such evidence is admissible, however, when it tends to establish 
  (1) motive; (2) intent; (3) the absence of mistake or accident; (4) a common 
  scheme or plan embracing the commission of two or more crimes so related to 
  each other that proof of one tends to establish the proof of the other; or (5) 
  the identity of the person charged with the present crime.Â  See State 
  v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923); Rule 404(b), SCRE; see also 
  Anderson v. State, 354 S.C. 431, 581 S.E.2d 834 (2003) (explaining that 
  Rule 404, the modern expression of the Lyle rule, excludes evidence of 
  other crimes, wrongs, or acts offered to prove character of person in order 
  to show action in conformity therewith; the rule creates an exception when testimony 
  is offered to show motive, identity, existence of common scheme or plan, absence 
  of mistake or accident, or intent).Â  If there is any evidence to support the 
  admission of bad act evidence, the trial judgeâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed 
  on appeal.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001).
The bad act must logically relate 
  to the crime with which the defendant has been charged.Â  Beck, 342 S.C. 
  at 135, 536 S.E.2d at 682-83; State v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 514 S.E.2d 
  578 (1999) (declaring that record must support logical relevance between prior 
  bad act and crime for which defendant is accused).Â Â Â  The trial judge must exclude 
  the evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger 
  of unfair prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Braxton, 343 S.C. 629, 
  541 S.E.2d 833 (2001); Beck, 342 S.C. at 135-36, 536 S.E.2d at 683; Rule 
  403, SCRE.
We rule Tamika Lambertâ€™s testimony 
  was admissible as tending to establish Paganâ€™s identity.Â  After Pagan fled the 
  scene for failing to stop for the blue light, he told Lambert that he was accused 
  of killing a woman, and that â€œMonicaâ€ was to blame for his trouble.Â  Lambertâ€™s 
  eyewitness testimony was relevant in putting Paganâ€™s flight into context.Â  The 
  testimony proved Pagan was attempting to flee from police because he was charged 
  with murdering the victim in the present case, and that he blamed the Stateâ€™s 
  key witness, Monique Ellerbee Cooks, for his situation.Â  This testimony was 
  logically relevant as evidence of Paganâ€™s identity because it connected the 
  murder with Paganâ€™s flight from the police one year later.
We conclude Tamika Lambertâ€™s testimony 
  was properly admitted as evidence of Paganâ€™s identity under Rule 404(b), SCRE.
IV.Â  Harmless 
  Error 
Assuming arguendo the trial 
  judge erred in admitting Tamika Lambertâ€™s testimony, we find such error was 
  harmless.
Whether an error is harmless depends 
  on the circumstances of the particular case.Â  In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 
  53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003); State v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 508 S.E.2d 
  870 (1998); State v. Thompson, 352 S.C. 552, 575 S.E.2d 77 (Ct. App. 
  2003).Â  â€œNo definite rule of law governs this finding; rather, the materiality 
  and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship 
  to the entire case.â€Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 
  150, 151 (1985).
Error is harmless where it could 
  not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.Â  In re Harvey, 
  355 S.C. at 63, 584 S.E.2d at 897; Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d 
  at 151; State v. Burton, 326 S.C. 605, 486 S.E.2d 762 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  
  Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial 
  errors not affecting the result.Â  State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 
  S.E.2d 595 (1991); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. 
  App. 2003).Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial 
  is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such 
  that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 
  S.C. 1, 377 S.E.2d 581 (1989); Adams, 354 S.C. at 381, 580 S.E.2d at 
  795; see also State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 460 S.E.2d 368 (1995) 
  (noting that when guilt is conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that 
  no other rational conclusion could be reached, this Court will not set aside 
  conviction for insubstantial errors not affecting result).Â  The admission of 
  improper evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other 
  evidence.Â  State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 577 S.E.2d 445 (2003); State 
  v. Braxton, 343 S.C. 629, 541 S.E.2d 833 (2001); State v. Blackburn, 
  271 S.C. 324, 247 S.E.2d 334 (1978); State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. 460, 
  523 S.E.2d 787 (Ct. App. 1999); see also State v. Williams, 321 
  S.C. 455, 469 S.E.2d 49 (1996) (instructing that error in admission of evidence 
  is harmless where it is cumulative to other evidence which was properly admitted); 
  State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993) (explicating 
  that any error in admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence 
  is harmless).
At trial, the State presented evidence 
  of two incidents in Paganâ€™s past that demonstrated his attempts to avoid arrest 
  or prosecution.Â  First, while under investigation for the murder in the case 
  sub judice, Pagan fled to his motherâ€™s home in New Jersey and 
  refused to return to South Carolina.Â  On January 21, 1998, six days after an 
  arrest warrant was issued, Pagan phoned Lt. Carlos Raines and told Raines that 
  he would turn himself in.Â  When this did not occur, United States Marshals located 
  Pagan in New Jersey approximately one month later, arrested him, and arranged 
  for transport to South Carolina.
Second, in 1995, Pagan was charged 
  with failure to stop for a blue lightâ€”the same type of offense that formed the 
  basis of Tamika Lambertâ€™s testimony.Â  Pagan stated: â€œIn 1995, I caught a parole 
  violation due to a failure to stop for a blue light. . . . I came [to South 
  Carolina] in â€˜95 to see my kids; thatâ€™s when I caught the failure to stop for 
  a blue light.Â  And I went back home [to New Jersey] and thatâ€™s when they violated 
  my parole.â€Â  In addition to this prior flight and parole violation evidence, 
  the State introduced Paganâ€™s criminal record, which included two convictions 
  for conspiracy to distribute crack cocaine.Â  Extensive testimony was presented 
  regarding Paganâ€™s various stays in prison.Â  Pagan admitted violating certain 
  rules and regulations of the Department of Corrections by getting married while 
  incarcerated at Palmer Pre-Release Center and possessing a cell phone.
Moreover, the State presented a witness, 
  Lavenia Helton, who testified regarding an argument between the victim and Pagan 
  that occurred prior to the murder of the victim.Â  In early December of 1997, 
  the victim and Pagan were at Heltonâ€™s apartment.Â  The victim attempted to leave 
  the apartment with a bag of crack cocaine.Â  Pagan told the victim, â€œBitch, give 
  me my shit.â€Â  The victim handed the bag containing the crack cocaine to Pagan, 
  who had a gun in his hand.Â  Pagan then told the victim, â€œBitch you gone die.â€
Because 
  there was testimony regarding other episodes of flight, prior convictions, a 
  parole violation, violations of Department of Corrections rules and regulations, 
  and a previous incident of violence between Pagan and the victim, Lambertâ€™s 
  testimony did not have a substantial effect upon Paganâ€™s trial.Â  We hold Tamika 
  Lambertâ€™s testimony was cumulative to the evidence presented by the State at 
  trial.Â  Any error in admitting this testimony was harmless.
CONCLUSION 

The trial judge did not err in admitting 
  Tamika Lambertâ€™s testimony that Pagan ran from police while out on bond for 
  the murder charge.Â  Lambertâ€™s testimony was admissible as (1) flight and â€œguilty

title: In the Interest of: Christopher H.
description: In this criminal case, Christopher H pled guilty to grand larceny and first-degree burglary without representation by counsel. We reverse and remand for a new trial finding Christopher did not validly waive his right to counsel persuant to Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806 (1975).
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
       
        In the Interest of: Christopher 
          H., a minor under the age of seventeen, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington 
  County
  J.L. Murdock, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge
  William J. McLeod, Family Court 
  Judge
  James A. Spruill, III, Family 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3725
  Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 20, 2004

REVERSED and REMANDED

 
   
     
       
        Assistant Appellate Defender 
          Tara S. Taggart,Â  of the SC Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, 
          for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
          Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Assistant Attorney General 
          W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia;Â  andÂ  Solicitor Jay E. Hodge, Jr., 
          of Darlington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Christopher 
  H. pled guilty to grand larceny and first-degree burglary and was committed 
  to the Department of Juvenile Justice for an indeterminate period not to exceed 
  his twenty-first birthday.Â  He was not represented by counsel at any of his 
  juvenile hearings.Â  Christopher argues on appeal that: (1) he did not validly 
  waive his right to counsel pursuant to Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 
  806 (1975); and, (2) his guilty plea was not knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently 
  entered.Â Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial.Â  
FACTS 

Christopher H. was charged in Darlington 
  County with the following five offenses that occurred between March and September 
  of 2001:Â  (1) grand larceny of a Yamaha four-wheeler, (2) assault and battery, 
  (3) first-degree burglary, (4) grand larceny of a Honda four-wheeler, and (5) 
  second-degree burglary.Â  At his 48-hour detention hearing, the assistant solicitor 
  told the judge that the clerkâ€™s office had screened Christopher and his legal 
  guardian and determined they did not qualify for a public defender.Â  Although 
  Christopher did not have counsel, the public defender sat in on the detention 
  hearing.Â  The judge ordered detention until a hearing the following Tuesday.Â  
  At the conclusion of the detention hearing, the solicitor noted that he had 
  advised Christopherâ€™s legal guardian that she needed to retain counsel for him. 
  The judge responded:Â  â€œYes.Â  You would need â€“ If you donâ€™t qualify for the Public 
  Defender, you do need to go ahead and retain private counsel.Â  These offenses 
  are of a very serious nature, so, you know, he needs some representation in 
  this case.â€Â  
Christopherâ€™s ten-day detention hearing 
  was held at the same time as five other juvenilesâ€™ detention hearings.Â  Several 
  of the juveniles were represented by the public defender.Â  When Christopherâ€™s 
  turn came, the public defender stated:Â  â€œYour Honor, on the [Christopher H.] 
  child, I remember that I stood with him last week but he did not qualify.Â  His 
  parents made too much money.Â  Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re not representing him.â€Â  The judge 
  responded â€œOkay,â€ and asked if Christopher had anything to tell him.Â  Christopher 
  stated in response, â€œI donâ€™t have nothing really to say.Â  I did all the crimes 
  and I committed them and I did them and thatâ€™s my fault.â€Â  When the judge asked 
  what he was charged with, the solicitor initially listed all five charges.Â  
  Later, however, the solicitor stated that Christopher was charged with only 
  two offenses, second-degree burglary and grand larceny of a Yamaha four-wheeler.Â  
  The solicitor further noted:

   He is not represented.Â  The parents 
    do not qualify for the Public Defender.Â  I told them, approached them and 
    talked with them and told them that if he was guilty, it would be in his interest 
    to go ahead and plead today and the recommendation would be that heâ€™d be committed 
    to Midlands for an evaluation . . . .Â Â  

The judge questioned Christopher 
  directly:

   
    THE COURT:
    Now youâ€™ve heard the Solicitor 
      and you heard what he said.Â  Do you feel like youâ€™re threatened or coerced 
      in any way by anyone?
  
   
    CHRISTOPHER:
    
      
        No, sir.
      
    
  
   
    THE COURT:
    Did you do the things youâ€™re 
      accused of?
  
   
    CHRISTOPHER:
    
      
        Yes, sir.
      
    
  
   
    THE COURT:
    Do you understand that weâ€™d 
      give you a trial if youâ€™d like it and put up witnesses and that kind of 
      thing?
  
   
    CHRISTOPHER:
    
      
        Yes, sir.
      
    
  
   
    THE COURT:
    Understanding that, do you still 
      wish to plead delinquent?
  
   
    CHRISTOPHER:
    
      
        Yes, sir.
      
    
  
   
    THE COURT:
    Are you delinquent?
  
   
    CHRISTOPHER: 
    
      
        Yes, sir.
      
    
  
   
    THE COURT:
    Did you break in the church?
  
   
    CHRISTOPHER:
    
      
        Yes, sir.
      
    
  
   
    THE COURT: 
    Did you steal the four-wheeler?
  
   
    CHRISTOPHER:
    
      
        Yes, sir.
      
    
  
   
    THE COURT:
    And no one has forced you to 
      plead this way?Â  You understand that we can send you away for a while?
  
   
    CHRISTOPHER:
    
      
        Yes, sir.
      
    
  
   
    THE COURT: 
    Understanding that, do you still 
      wish to plead delinquent?
  
  
    CHRISTOPHER:
    
      
        Yes, sir.Â  
      
    
  

Thereafter, the family court judge 
  ordered that Christopher be committed to the Department of Juvenile Justice 
  for evaluation for a period not to exceed forty-five days. 
  [1]  
At Christopherâ€™s dispositional hearing, 
  the State presented its report recommending commitment.Â  Christopher was not 
  represented by an attorney and the judge was advised that he had never had an 
  attorney.Â  After hearing briefly from the solicitor and from Christopherâ€™s legal 
  guardian, the judge committed him for an indeterminate period of time not to 
  exceed his twenty-first birthday.Â  Christopher appeals.Â Â Â  
  Â 
DISCUSSION 


   1. Did Christopher validly 
    waive his right to counsel?

The right to counsel is guaranteed 
  by the Sixth Amendment of the United States Constitution and extends to juvenile 
  proceedings.Â  See e.g. In re Winship, 397 U.S. 358 (1970).Â  
  â€œA defendant may surrender his right to counsel through (1) waiver by affirmative, 
  verbal request; (2) waiver by conduct; and (3) forfeiture.â€Â  State v. Thompson, 
  355 S.C. 255, 262, 584 S.E.2d 131, 134 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
Christopher argues that he did not 
  waive his right to counsel because the family court judge did not comply with 
  the procedures set forth in Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806 (1975).Â Â  
  A valid waiver of counsel, either by affirmative, verbal request or by conduct, 
  requires compliance with Faretta.Â  See Thompson, 355 S.C. 
  atÂ  263, 584 S.E.2d at 135 (â€œâ€˜[T]o the extent that the defendant's actions are 
  examined under the doctrine of 'waiver,' there can be no valid waiver of the 
  Sixth Amendment right to counsel unless the defendant also receives Faretta warnings.â€™Â  Any subsequent misconduct will be treated 
  as a â€˜waiver by conduct.â€™â€)(citations omitted).
Faretta allows an accused 
  to waive his right to counsel if he is (1) advised of his right to counsel, 
  and (2) adequately warned of the dangers of self-representation.Â  Prince 
  v. State, 301 S.C. 422, 424, 392 S.E.2d 462, 463 (1990).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[i]n 
  the absence of a specific inquiry by the trial judge addressing the disadvantages 
  of a pro se defense as required by the second Faretta prong, [the 
  appellate court] will look to the record to determine whether petitioner had 
  sufficient background or was apprised of his rights by some other source.â€Â  
  Id.Â  (citation omitted). To determine if an accused has sufficient background 
  to comprehend the dangers of self-representation, courts consider a variety 
  of factors including: 
 (1)  the accusedâ€™s age, educational 
  background, and physical and mental health; 
  (2)  whether the accused 
  was previously involved in criminal trials; 
  (3)  whether the accused 
  knew the nature of the charge(s) and of the possible penalties; 
  (4)  whether the accused 
  was represented by counsel before trial and whether that attorney explained 
  to him the dangers of self-representation; 
  ( 5)  whether the accused 
  was attempting to delay or manipulate the proceedings; 
  (6)  whether the court 
  appointed stand-by counsel;
  (7)  whether the accused 
  knew he would be required to comply with the rules of procedure at trial; 
  (8)  whether the accused 
  knew of the legal challenges he could raise in defense to the charge(s) against 
  him; 
  (9)  whether the exchange 
  between the accused and the court consisted merely of pro forma answers 
  to pro forma questions; and 
  (10) whether the accusedâ€™s 
  waiver resulted from either coercion or mistreatment.
Gardner v. State, 351 S.C. 
  407, 412-13, 570 S.E.2d 184, 186-87 (2002).Â  
The record in this case reveals that 
  that neither the judge at the adjudicatory hearing nor the judge at the dispositional 
  hearing complied with the procedures in Faretta.Â  Initially, Christopher 
  was never adequately advised of his right to an attorney.Â  At Christopherâ€™s 
  48-hour detention hearing, the judge urged Christopherâ€™s legal guardian to find 
  representation because of the serious nature of the charges.Â  At Christopherâ€™s 
  adjudicatory hearing, the judge merely asked him if he understood that the court 
  would â€œgive [him] a trial if [heâ€™d] like it and put up witnesses and that kind 
  of thing.â€Â  Although the solicitor stated he had spoken with Christopherâ€™s legal 
  guardian about acquiring representation, that by itself does not meet the requirements 
  of Faretta.Â  See Watts v. State, 347 S.C. 399, 403, 556 
  S.E.2d 368, 371 (2001) (finding the plea judge ineffectively warned of the dangers 
  of appearing pro se when, among other things, he â€œpermitted the solicitor 
  to relate the circumstances of Petitionerâ€™s release of his appointed attorneyâ€) 
  (emphasis in original). Additionally, the record does not indicate Christopher 
  ever elected to proceed pro se.Â  See State v. Reed, 332 
  S.C. 35, 41, 503 S.E.2d 747, 750 (â€œThe right to proceed pro se must be 
  clearly asserted by the defendant prior to trial.â€).
Moreover, both family court judges 
  failed to comply with Faretta because Christopher was never adequately 
  warned of the dangers of self-representation.Â  In addition, the record reflects 
  that Christopher has an insufficient background to comprehend the dangers of 
  self-representation based on an application of the Gardner factors: (1) 
  Christopher was sixteen years old at the time of the proceedings, but his psychosocial 
  report states that he â€œappears emotionally and physically younger than his stated 
  age.â€Â  Christopher has a full scale IQ of seventy-four (borderline range) and 
  his last year in school was the tenth grade.Â  (2) It appears from the record 
  that Christopher had been to family court before, but it is unclear as to the 
  nature of his family court experience.Â  (3) Nothing in the record indicates 
  that Christopher had any knowledge of the nature of the charges or the possible 
  penalties.Â  Instead, Christopher merely indicated his willingness to accept 
  responsibility for certain acts he had committed.Â  (4) Christopher never appeared 
  represented by counsel.Â  While the public defender sat through Christopherâ€™s 
  initial detention hearing, it is unclear whether he had any active involvement 
  or communication with Christopher. (5) There is nothing in the record to indicate 
  Christopher was attempting to delay or manipulate the proceedings.Â  (6) The 
  court did not appoint stand-by counsel.Â  (7) The record does not indicate Christopher 
  had any knowledge that he needed to comply with any rules of procedure or (8) 
  any of the legal challenges he could raise in his defense.Â  (9) The exchange 
  between Christopher and the family court judges amounted to little more than 
  pro forma questions and answers.Â  (10) Notwithstanding, the record does 
  not suggest that Christopherâ€™s appearance without counsel was a result of coercion 
  or mistreatment.Â Â  See Gardner, 351 S.C. at 412-13, 570 S.E.2d 
  at 186-87.
We find the record in this case does 
  not show that Christopher knowingly and intelligently waived his right to counsel.Â  
  Furthermore, nothing in the record suggests Christopher forfeited his right 
  to counsel.Â  See Thompson, 355 S.C. at 267, 584 S.E.2d at 137 
  (stating that forfeiture requires extremely dilatory conduct and situations 
  involving forfeiture are unusual, typically involving a manipulative or disruptive 
  defendant).Â  
The typical remedy for failing to 
  show a knowing and intelligent waiver of counsel is to remand to the trial court 
  for an evidentiary hearing to determine whether the waiver was, in fact, knowingly 
  and intelligently made.Â  State v. Dixon, 269 S.C. 107, 236 S.E.2d 419 
  (1977).Â  However, this court can grant an appellant a new trial without an evidentiary 
  hearing if it is clear that a hearing on remand would serve no useful purpose.Â  
  State v. Cash, 304 S.C. 223, 225, 403 S.E.2d 632, 634 (1991).Â Â  Because 
  we find the record clearly reflects that the family court failed to adequately 
  advise Christopher of the right to counsel, failed to make a specific inquiry 
  as to Christopherâ€™s knowledge of the dangers of self-representation, and demonstrated 
  that Christopher has an insufficient background to comprehend the dangers of 
  self-representation, we find that remanding this case for a factual determination 
  as to whether the waiver was knowingly and intelligently made would serve no 
  useful purpose.Â Â  Instead, we reverse and remand for a new trial.

  2. Did Christopher knowingly, 
    voluntarily, and intelligently enter a plea of guilty? 

Because we reverse and remand for a 
new trial on the right to counsel issue, we need not reach the issue concerning 
the voluntariness of his guilty plea.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing 
of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling 
that an appellate court need not review remaining issues when disposition of prior 
issues are dispositive).
Accordingly, we reverse and remand 
  for a new trial.Â  
REVERSED and REMANDED.
ANDERSON and CURETON, JJ., concur.



 
  1 
    Â While this appeal was pending, Christopher petitioned this court for supersedeas, 
    habeas corpus, or other relief, arguing he was not advised of the right to 
    counsel and risks of proceeding pro se.Â  This court denied the request 
    for habeas corpus and remanded the petition for supersedeas to the family 
    court.Â  Because this court remanded the petition for supersedeas only, the 
    issue concerning Christopherâ€™s right to counsel remained before us.Â  On remand, 
    however, the family court granted Christopherâ€™s motion for supersedeas.Â  While 
    both the adjudicatory and dispositional orders originally stated that Christopher 
    pleaded guilty to all five charges, the orders were amended following the 
    remand to reflect Christopherâ€™s plea to only two of the five charges.Â Â Â Â Â

title: Bowman v Bowman
description: In this divorce action, Husband appeals family court's denial of his Rule 60(b)(2) motion to set aside its judgment against him.  He also challenges the adequacy of attorney fees and suit monies he was awarded.  The court of appeals affirmed on all issues.
text:
THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Carl W. Bowman, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Norma M. Bowman, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington 
  County
  Â Richard W. Chewning, III, 
  Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3726
  Heard November 4, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  January 20, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Cynthia Barrier Castengera, 
          of Newland, North Carolina; J. Mark Taylor and C. Vance Stricklin, both 
          of West Columbia, for Appellant.
        F. Glenn Smith, of Columbia, 
          for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â Â Â Â  
  The family court granted Carl W. Bowman (Husband) a divorce from 
  Norma M. Bowman (Wife), equitably divided the marital estate, and awarded Husband 
  attorney fees and suit monies. Following the denial of the partiesâ€™ Rule 59(e), 
  SCRCP, motions, Husband filed a Rule 60(b)(2) and (3) motion to set aside the 
  judgment. The family court denied the motion.Â  On appeal Husband challenges 
  the adequacy of the attorney fee and suit money award and the denial of his 
  Rule 60(b)(2) and (3) motion.Â  We affirm.
 
  FACTS
  In July 1997, after 
    thirty-five years of marriage, Husband filed an action for divorce seeking 
    equitable division of the marital estate, attorney fees, and suit monies.Â  
    Wife admitted to adultery in her pleadings, and the paramount issue remaining 
    was the equitable division of the marital estate.Â  Each party challenged the 
    inclusion in the marital estate of his and her respective retirement plans, [1]  and Wife contested Husbandâ€™s claim for attorney fees and suit 
    monies.Â Â Â   

The family court issued an order 
  granting Husband a divorce, excluding Wifeâ€™s defined benefit plan from the marital 
  estate, including Husbandâ€™s retirement plan in the marital estate, and awarding 
  Husband $7,048 in attorney fees and suit monies.Â  The court further requested 
  that the parties attempt to reach an agreement concerning the division of marital 
  property to accomplish the equitable division of 60% to Husband and 40% to Wife.Â  
  The parties were unable to resolve all issues, necessitating the family courtâ€™s 
  involvement in concluding the matter.Â   
Both parties filed Rule 59(e) motions, 
  which were denied.Â  Thereafter, upon receipt of information through post-judgment 
  discovery concerning the funding source of Wifeâ€™s defined benefit plan, Husband 
  sought relief from the judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b)(2) and (3).Â  The family 
  court denied the motion, primarily finding Husband could have discovered the 
  information prior to trial.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW 

In appeals from the family court, 
  this court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its view of the 
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 
  204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, 
  require this court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson 
  v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  The decision 
  to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b) is within the sound discretion of 
  the trial court.Â  Coleman v. Dunlap, 306 S.C. 491, 494, 413 S.E.2d 15, 
  17 (1992).Â  On review, we are limited to determining whether the trial court 
  abused its discretion in granting or denying such a motion.Â  Saro Invs. v. 
  Ocean Holiday Pâ€™ship, 314 S.C. 116, 124, 441 S.E.2d 835, 840 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  
  

  LAW/ANALYSIS
  
I. Exclusion of Wifeâ€™s Defined Benefit 
Plan from the Marital Estate and the Denial of Husbandâ€™s Rule 60(b)(2) and (3) 
Motion 
Husband argues the family court erred 
  in not granting a new trial as he sought a second opportunity to persuade the 
  court to include Wifeâ€™s defined benefit plan in the marital estate.Â  Specifically, 
  Husband asserts the family court erred in denying his Rule 60(b)(2) and (3) 
  motion after Husband provided evidence that Wifeâ€™s defined benefit plan was 
  funded, at least in part, from life insurance policies purchased by Wifeâ€™s employer 
  during the marriage. As noted, marital litigation commenced in July 1997.Â  Wifeâ€™s 
  defined benefit plan was created on July 1, 1998 and was funded in June 1999.Â  
  It is stipulated that Wifeâ€™s defined plan â€œwas substantially funded at its inception.â€Â  
  The family court reasoned that since Wife did not own the defined benefit plan 
  until after marital litigation was filed, the retirement plan should be excluded 
  from the marital estate.Â  Husband appeals from the denial of his Rule 60(b)(2) 
  and (3) motion. [2] 
The new evidence submitted post-judgment 
  in support of Husbandâ€™s Rule 60(b)(2) and (3) motion consists of a statement 
  from Wifeâ€™s employer, the South Carolina Student Loan Corporation, showing that 
  the assets of the defined benefit plan include the cash surrender values of 
  eight life insurance policies with New York Life Insurance Company.Â  Additional 
  evidence reveals that one of the policies was purchased in 1988, and Wife was 
  listed as the named insured.Â  While we agree with Husband that this information 
  establishes a nexus between Wifeâ€™s defined benefit plan and the cash surrender 
  values of the life insurance policies as a funding source for the plan, 
  [3]  we find Husbandâ€™s Rule 60(b)(2) and (3) motion was nevertheless properly 
  denied.Â  We consider it unnecessary to explore the differing standards between 
  Rule 60 (b)(2) and (3) as advanced by Husband, for we conclude that South Carolinaâ€™s 
  strong policy towards finality of judgments trumps a partyâ€™s ability to set 
  aside a judgment where, as here, the party could have discovered the evidence 
  prior to trial.Â  SeeÂ  Bryan v. Bryan, 220 S.C. 164, 168, 66 S.E.2d 
  609, 610 (1951) (finding that equitable relief from a judgment is not available 
  for intrinsic fraud â€œon the theory that an issue which has been tried and passed 
  upon in the original action should not be retried in an action of equitable 
  relief, and that otherwise litigation would be interminableâ€);Â  Chewning 
  v. Ford Motor Co., 354 S.C. 72, 86, 579 S.E.2d 605, 613 (2003) (finding 
  that while post-judgment relief was granted as a result of â€œunique facts,â€ the 
  court reaffirmed South Carolinaâ€™s â€œlongstanding policy towards final judgmentsâ€).Â  
  
Husband invites this court to apply 
  the â€œmisconductâ€ standard in Rule 60(b)(3).Â  Were we to do so, we would still 
  be constrained to affirm the family court.Â  The cases cited by Husband permit 
  Rule 60(b)(3) relief only where â€œthe misconduct prevented the moving party from 
  fully presenting its case.â€Â  Schultz v. Butcher, 24 Fed.3d 626, 630 (4th 
  Cir. 1994) citing Square Constr. Co. v. Washington Metro. Area Transit Auth., 
  657 Fed.2d 68, 71 (4th Cir. 1981); Anderson v. Cryovac, Inc., 862 Fed.2d 
  910, 924 (1st Cir. 1988) (stating â€œthe challenged behavior must substantially 
  have interfered with the aggrieved partyâ€™s ability fully and fairly to prepare 
  for and proceed at trialâ€) (emphasis in original); see also Rycroft 
  v. Tanguay, 279 S.C. 76, 79, 302 S.E.2d 327, 329 (1983) (stating â€œequity 
  will not grant relief to one against whom an unfavorable judgment has been rendered, 
  even in consequence of fraud, where the aggrieved party has not acted with diligenceâ€); 
  Dunn v. Consolidated Rail Corp., 890 F.Supp. 1262, 1269 (M.D.La. 1995) 
  (stating â€œ[a] Rule 60(b)(3) assertion . . . must be such as to prevent the losing 
  party from fully and fairly presenting its case or defenseâ€).
Here, Husband was aware of Wifeâ€™s 
  defined benefit plan, as well as her management position with the South Carolina 
  Student Loan Corporation.Â  Wife acknowledged this post-filing retirement account 
  at her May 11, 2000 deposition, approximately seven months prior to trial.Â  
  Also prior to trial, Husband noticed the deposition of James Kenneth Player, 
  the executive vice president of Wifeâ€™s employer, for the purpose of gaining 
  additional evidence and information concerning the defined benefit plan.Â  However, 
  Husband elected not to take Playerâ€™s deposition, opting instead to enter into 
  the following stipulation with Wife:

  As to [Wifeâ€™s] plan, we will stipulate 
    that the defined benefits were not created until after the date of filing.Â  
    The plan was funded by the South Carolina Student Loan Corporation.Â  The plan 
    was substantially funded at its inception.Â  The plan utilized past â€œtime of 
    serviceâ€ to calculate the initial contribution to the plan.Â  We stipulate 
    that this is what [Wifeâ€™s employer] and/or [Wife] would otherwise testify 
    to if called as a witness.

Husband was thus aware prior to 
  trial of this asset and Wifeâ€™s reluctance to disclose it.Â  Significantly, 
  Husband faced no legal impediment prior to trial precluding his access to information 
  concerning any aspect of Wifeâ€™s defined benefit plan, including the planâ€™s funding 
  source.Â  Against this procedural history, Husband elected not to pursue further 
  discovery, and he entered into the above stipulation.Â  Absent valid grounds 
  for Rule 60(b) relief, an unfavorable ruling at trial does not provide an unsuccessful 
  litigant another opportunity to litigate an issue.Â  We find no abuse of discretion 
  and therefore affirm the family courtâ€™s denial of Husbandâ€™s Rule 60(b)(2) and 
  (3) motion. 
We in no manner condone Wifeâ€™s noncompliance 
  with the rules regarding discovery supplementation, and we are not unsympathetic 
  with litigants, like Husband, who encounter adversaries who display a deliberate 
  indifference to the discovery rules. [4] Â  We further recognize the myriad 
  difficulties and vagaries inherent in the family court arena for judges and 
  practitioners alike.
In this case, Husband is ultimately 
  not prejudiced by the denial of Rule 60(b) relief, for we are persuaded that 
  the family court correctly excluded Wifeâ€™s defined benefit plan from the marital 
  estate.Â  The post-judgment discovery does little to advance Husbandâ€™s argument, 
  as it simply bolsters the prior stipulation that the â€œplan was substantially 
  funded at its inception.â€Â  The life insurance policies at issue are best described 
  as corporate assets, which Wife neither controlled nor had the right to control 
  based on the record before us.
We believe it useful to the family 
  court bench and bar to provide a general framework within which to address and 
  properly classify employment related benefits, such as a retirement plan, purportedly 
  created after the date of filing of marital litigation but prior to dissolution 
  of the marriage.Â  We do so in recognition of the reality that some spouses in 
  anticipation of, and during, marital litigation have a lamentable tendency to 
  engage in a variety of deceptive acts and practices to secrete assets. [5] 
For property to be included within 
  the term â€œmarital property,â€ two factors must exist:Â  property must be (1) â€œacquired 
  . . . during the marriageâ€ and (2) â€œowned as of the date of filing or commencement 
  of marital litigation.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2002).Â  The â€œacquired 
  during marriageâ€ component is generally established by showing that the property 
  relates to compensation earned or effort expended during the marriage.Â  See 
  Mallett v. Mallett, 323 S.C. 141, 150, 473 S.E.2d 804, 810 (Ct. App. 
  1996) (stating â€œ[u]pon dissolution of the marriage, property acquired during 
  the marriage should be divided and distributed in a manner which fairly reflects 
  each spouseâ€™s contribution to its acquisition, regardless of which spouse holds 
  legal title.â€);Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 297, 372 S.E.2d 107, 
  111 (Ct. App. 1988) (finding only the appreciation in value of assets â€œresulting 
  directly or indirectly from the efforts of the parties was marital propertyâ€).Â  
  The â€œownershipâ€ prong, while ostensibly straightforward, can raise troublesome 
  issues.Â  A technical application of the â€œownershipâ€ prong may in some cases 
  invite fraud, resulting in the improper exclusion of property from the marital 
  estate, which, we believe, would be contrary to legislative intent.Â  For example, 
  a party may sufficiently possess an ascertainable interest in or entitlement 
  to property â€œacquired during the marriage,â€ yet purposefully delay ownership 
  until after marital litigation has commenced.Â  In such an example, the partyâ€™s 
  interest in and entitlement to ownership is sufficient to conclude the â€œownershipâ€ 
  prong has been satisfied. [6] Â  To conclude otherwise would promote fraud, reward misconduct, 
  and contravene legislative intent.
Regarding retirement plans and employment 
  benefits created after the commencement of marital litigation but before dissolution, 
  the mere fact that some aspect of the plan or benefit may relate to service 
  during the partiesâ€™ marriage does not mandate inclusion in the marital estate.Â  
  Indeed, virtually all retirement plans and employment benefits are connected 
  in some manner to an employeeâ€™s prior service.Â  Further, an employer may, completely 
  independent of the employee, institute a retirement plan or benefit after commencement 
  of marital litigation.Â  Depending on the totality of the facts and circumstances, 
  the employee-spouse may not have an interest in or entitlement to such plan 
  or benefit at the time of marital litigation, i.e., a bona fide 
  absence of ownership when marital litigation is commenced.
The mere fact that technical ownership 
  of a retirement plan or employment benefit is delayed until after the commencement 
  of marital litigation does not mandate its exclusion from the marital estate.Â Â  
  Where a party possesses an ascertainable interest in or entitlement to property 
  during the marriage, the partyâ€™s attempts to delay technical ownership status 
  until after marital litigation has commenced shall not prevent a finding of 
  the requisite â€œownershipâ€ necessary for inclusion in the marital estate.Â  Therefore, 
  where lack of ownership status as of the date of marital litigation is attributable 
  to any purposeful act or omission by the spouse, the property shall be deemed 
  â€œownedâ€ within the meaning of Â§ 20-7-473 so as to include the marital portion 
  in the marital estate.Â Â Â  
Resolution of this marital property 
  classification dilemma is certainly fact-intensive, and no bright line test 
  will suffice.Â  We continue to recognize and respect the broad discretion accorded 
  to family court judges in the fact-sensitive inquiries surrounding the identification 
  of marital and nonmarital property as well as the determination of the equitable 
  distribution of the marital estate.Â  See Murphy v. Murphy, 319 
  S.C. 324, 329, 461 S.E.2d 39, 41 (1995) (stating â€œ[f]amily court judges have 
  wide discretion in determining how marital property is to be distributedâ€) (citation 
  omitted).
II. Inclusion of Husbandâ€™s Retirement 
Plan in the Marital Estate 
Husband argues the family court erred 
  in including his retirement plan in the marital estate, valuing the plan as 
  of the filing date of marital litigation, and apportioning 40% of the planâ€™s 
  monthly payments to Wife. 
In May 1996, approximately one year 
  before the filing of marital litigation, Husbandâ€™s employer, South Carolina 
  Electric and Gas (SCE&G), informed Husband that his position would be â€œeliminated 
  as of June 30, 1996.â€Â  SCE&G extended Husband three â€œseverance options.â€Â  
  On May 30, 1996, Husband elected the third option, referred to as â€œsix monthsâ€™ 
  severance and early retirement.â€Â  The six monthsâ€™ â€œseverance payâ€ amounted to 
  $46,332 and was paid to Husband on or about July 1, 1996.Â  Monthly payments 
  to Husband pursuant to the early retirement option also began in July 1996, 
  one year prior to the commencement of marital litigation. The family court included 
  Husbandâ€™s early retirement benefit in the marital estate.Â  Husband, referring 
  to this asset exclusively as â€œseverance pay,â€ assigns error to its consideration 
  as marital property and inclusion in the marital estate.Â Â Â  
We initially clarify the true nature 
  of this asset.Â  The â€œseverance optionâ€ exercised by Husband in May 1996 consisted 
  of two components:Â  (1) severance pay of $46,332; and (2) a â€œSpecial Incentive 
  Retirement Benefitâ€ paid in monthly installments over a multi-year period.Â  
  We find these benefits were â€œacquired during the marriageâ€ in the sense that 
  the payments were compensation for services performed during the course of the 
  marriage.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2002);Â  Tinsley v. 
  Tinsley, 326 S.C. 374, 381, 483 S.E.2d 198, 202 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The valuation 
  of these benefits by Raymond McKay, Husbandâ€™s expert, omits the actual severance 
  pay portion and includes only those retirement benefits due on or after the 
  date of filing of marital litigation.Â  McKay properly utilized a â€œvaluation 
  dateâ€ of July 9, 1997. [7]  Â He valued the retirement benefits at $326,148 at the time 
  of filing and $254,637 at the time of trial.Â  While Husband asserts error in 
  the inclusion of these benefits in the marital estate, the parties accept McKayâ€™s 
  methodology and valuation.Â  
We reject Husbandâ€™s continuing efforts 
  to characterize his retirement benefits as â€œseverance.â€Â  Not only does McKayâ€™s 
  valuation of these benefits exclude the severance benefits paid one year 
  prior to marital litigation, we adhere to South Carolinaâ€™s sound and established 
  approach of scrutinizing the true nature and purpose of the benefit.Â  See, 
  e.g., Mears v. Mears, 305 S.C. 150, 156, 406 S.E.2d 376, 380 (Ct. 
  App. 1991), overruled on other grounds by Marsh v. Marsh, 313 
  S.C. 42, 437 S.E.2d 34 (1993) (concluding proper classification of employment 
  termination benefits as marital or nonmarital property â€œdepends on the purpose 
  of the paymentsâ€);Â  Mallet, 323 S.C. at 152, 473 S.E.2d at 810 (holding 
  property classified as nonmarital because the â€œpurposeâ€ of the benefit was to 
  replace earnings after the date commencement of marital litigation);Â  Fisher 
  v. Fisher, 319 S.C. 500, 504, 462 S.E.2d 303, 305 (Ct. App. 1995) (finding 
  benefits paid pursuant to a â€œvoluntary separation incentiveâ€ were analogous 
  to an â€œearly retirement,â€ and the payments were thus deemed marital property 
  â€œunder the facts of this caseâ€); Tinsley, 326 S.C. at 381-82, 483 S.E.2d 
  at 202 (holding disability benefits were not marital property since the â€œpayments 
  are a replacement for income he would be earning currently and would be able 
  to earn in the future had he not become disabledâ€).Â  Thus, classification of 
  property as marital or nonmarital must be determined in light of the true nature 
  and purpose of the benefit.Â  South Carolina does not classify property as marital 
  or nonmarital based on the title or nomenclature assigned by a party.Â Â Â  
We find the family court correctly 
  classified Husbandâ€™s retirement benefits as marital property subject to equitable 
  distribution.Â  The benefits are compensation for services performed during marital 
  years and were, thus, acquired during the marriage and owned by Husband as of 
  the commencement of marital litigation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 
  (Supp. 2002).Â Â Â  
Husband next contends the family 
  court erred in valuing his retirement plan as of the date marital litigation 
  was filed.Â  A decrease in value occurred post-filing, solely attributable to 
  Husbandâ€™s expenditure of these funds after the filing date.Â  Husband suggests 
  a valuation as of the date of trial would be more appropriate.Â  We disagree 
  with Husbandâ€™s position for two reasons.Â  First, Husbandâ€™s proposed property 
  division relies on the July 1997 valuation date, with the plan value furnished 
  by Husbandâ€™s expert.Â  Second, Husbandâ€™s expenditure of these funds was voluntary.Â  
  Unlike the situation in Tinsley where disability payments by necessity 
  replaced future earnings, Husband acknowledged at trial his continuing ability 
  to work:Â  

   
    Wifeâ€™s counsel:
      
    Do you have any impediments 
      or disabilities at this time?
      
  
   
    Husband:Â  Â Â Â 
      
    No, sir.
      
  
   
    Wifeâ€™s counsel:
      
    Youâ€™re in good health?
      
  
   
    Husband:Â  Â 
      
    Are you talking about impediments 
      that would stop me from going to work?
      
  
   
    Wifeâ€™s counsel:
      
    Yes, sir.
      
  
   
    Husband:Â  Â Â 
      
    No, sir, I donâ€™t have any.
      
  
   
    Wifeâ€™s counsel:Â 
      
    Okay.Â  So you could go to work, 
      couldnâ€™t you?
      
  
  
    Husband:
      
    Yes, sir.
      
  

Accordingly, we concur with the family 
  courtâ€™s reliance on the statutory valuation date. 
  [8] 
Husbandâ€™s final argument in connection 
  with his retirement benefits is the family courtâ€™s award to Wife of a portion 
  of his monthly benefits.Â  In this regard, the family court did precisely what 
  Husband requested.Â  It adopted Husbandâ€™s proposed equitable division, and in 
  so doing, rejected Wifeâ€™s efforts to avoid the monthly pay-out from Husbandâ€™s 
  retirement benefits.Â  Husband may not seek and receive a particular result at 
  trial and then challenge it on appeal.Â  See, e.g., Bazzle v. 
  Green Tree Fin. Corp., 351 S.C. 244, 255, 569 S.E.2d 349, 355 (2002), vacated 
  and remanded on other grounds by Green Tree Fin.Â  Corp. v. Bazzle, 
  123 S.Ct. 2402 (2003) (stating â€œ[t]he courts of this state have recognized that 
  a party cannot complain when it receives the relief for which it has asked.â€).
Â We find the family court did not 
  err in including Husbandâ€™s retirement plan in the marital estate.Â  Further, 
  we find there was no error in the valuation or apportionment of the plan.
III. Adequacy of Award of Attorney 
Fees and Suit Monies 
Husband argues the family courtâ€™s 
  award of $7,048 in attorney fees and suit monies was inadequate.
â€œThe award of attorney fees in a 
  divorce action and the amount thereof are matters within the discretion of the 
  trial judge.â€Â  Sexton v. Sexton, 321 S.C. 487, 491, 469 S.E.2d 608, 611 
  (Ct. App. 1996) (citations omitted).Â  While we acknowledge that Husband incurred 
  litigation expenses in excess of the amount awarded, we find no abuse of discretion.Â  
  We affirm the family courtâ€™s award of attorney fees and suit monies in the amount 
  of $7,048.Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HOWARD, J., concur.Â  
  Â Â Â Â  



 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wifeâ€™s purchase money pension plan was, without objection, 
    included in the marital estate.Â  Regarding Wife, this appeal only concerns 
    her defined benefit plan that was created after the filing date of this action.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP, provides that judgments may be set aside 
    if there has been â€œnewly discovered evidence which by due diligence could 
    not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial under Rule 59(b) 
    . . . .â€Â  Under Rule 60(b)(3), SCRCP, judgments may also be set aside for 
    â€œfraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of an adverse party . . . .â€Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
    

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The family courtâ€™s error in concluding otherwise does not 
    require reversal.Â  As correctly determined by the family court, Husband could 
    have ascertained this information prior to trial.Â  

 
   
    [4]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  When invoked, the rules governing court procedures in general 
    and discovery in particular provide meaningful remedies and sanctions for 
    noncomplying parties and attorneys.Â  See, e.g., Rule 37, SCRCP.

 
   
    [5]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The issue in this case is limited to the proper classification 
    of an asset, though we acknowledge that such deception may go well beyond 
    asset classification and include efforts to assign unreasonable values to 
    assets, as well as artificially portraying earnings and earning capacity.

 
   
    [6]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  â€œSouth Carolina courts construe the term â€˜propertyâ€™ very broadly.Â  
    The term â€˜propertyâ€™ is a general term that is used to designate a right of 
    ownership and it includes every subject of whatever nature upon which the 
    right of ownership can legally attach, including choses in action.â€Â  Ball 
    v. Ball, 312 S.C. 31, 33, 430 S.E.2d 533, 534 (Ct. App. 1993).

 
   
    [7]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  McKayâ€™s analysis structures the monthly retirement benefits 
    at three levels.Â  Payments began on July 1, 1996.Â  McKayâ€™s valuation reflects 
    the benefits â€œin pay statusâ€ as of July 9, 1997, with 8.23 â€œyears pension 
    to be received.â€Â  The 8.23 years reflects the period from the commencement 
    date of marital litigation (the valuation date) to October 2005 when Husband 
    reaches age 62. The agreement between Husband and SCE&G anticipated a 
    reduced monthly benefit effective October 2005, which McKayâ€™s valuation recognizes.Â  
    The third level of benefits begins in October 2008 when Husband reaches age 
    65.Â  Close scrutiny of McKayâ€™s detailed valuation demonstrates the exclusion 
    of the severance pay as well as those retirement benefits paid before the 
    valuation date.Â  

 
   
    [8]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We do, however, recognize that passive post-filing changes 
    in the appreciation or depreciation of marital assets may be considered by 
    the family court in determining an equitable apportionment of the marital 
    estate.Â  See Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C. 222, 228, 512 S.E.2d 539, 
    542 (Ct. App. 1999).
