description: Domestic Action:  Wife appeals award of attorney fees, alimony, Husband's portion of Wife's IRA and as well as reimbursement for sum expended on marital home. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.
text:
Wade M. Jenkins v. Janna Grooms Watkins Jenkins


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Wade M. Jenkins, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Janna Grooms Watkins Jenkins, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â Judy C. Bridges, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3727
  Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed January 27, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED

 
   
     
      
        Cynthia Barrier Castengera, of Newland, N.C. and David Dusty Rhoades, 
          of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Joseph P. Cerato, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.: In this domestic action, Janna Grooms Watkins Jenkins 
  (â€œWifeâ€) appeals the family courtâ€™s award of attorney fees and alimony, arguing 
  the amounts are insufficient and should have included post-judgment interest.Â  
  Wife also appeals the family courtâ€™s decision awarding Wade M. Jenkins (â€œHusbandâ€) 
  a portion of Wifeâ€™s IRA, as well as reimbursement for sums expended on the marital 
  home.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.Â  
FACTS 
Husband and Wife were married in March 1987 and 
  separated in October 1997.Â  They have no children.Â  Husband instituted an action 
  for separate maintenance and support against Wife in January 1998.Â  The family 
  court granted the parties a divorce based on one yearâ€™s continuous separation, 
  ordered Husband to pay Wife $2,700 per month in rehabilitative alimony for one 
  year, equitably apportioned marital property, and awarded Wife $9,301.61 in 
  attorney fees.Â  After an appeal by Husband and cross-appeal by Wife, this court 
  affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.Â  This court ordered the family 
  court to award permanent periodic alimony instead of rehabilitative alimony; 
  to determine Husbandâ€™s entitlement to part of Wifeâ€™s IRA; to consider Husbandâ€™s 
  entitlement to reimbursement for certain sums paid; and to reconsider attorney 
  fees awarded to Wife. [1] Â  We denied Husbandâ€™s petition 
  for rehearing and the supreme court denied Husbandâ€™s petition for writ of certiorari.Â  

On remand, the family court awarded Wife $1,800 permanent periodic alimony 
  per month and ordered Husband to pay $200 per month toward his $23,400 alimony 
  arrearage; ordered Wife to pay Husband $2,250 for his share of Wifeâ€™s IRA; ordered 
  Wife to reimburse Husband $4,222.61; and ordered Husband to pay 75% of Wifeâ€™s 
  attorney fees.Â  The court did not award interest on the alimony arrearage or 
  Wifeâ€™s attorney fee award.Â  After Wifeâ€™s request for reconsideration, the court 
  ruled interest should run on the alimony arrearage from the date of the order 
  regarding remand.Â  The court again denied the award of interest on the attorney 
  fees.Â  Wife appeals.
 STANDARD OF REVIEW 
In appeals from the family court, this Court has the authority to find facts 
  in accordance with our view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Greene 
  v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 335, 569 S.E.2d 393, 397 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  This 
  broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the family 
  court.Â  Id.Â  Neither are we required to ignore the fact that the trial 
  judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate 
  their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Id.Â  
  The award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and 
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Dearybury 
  v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002). â€œAlimony is 
  a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  
  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 
  1988).
LAW/ANALYSIS
 I. Attorney Fees
Wife argues the family court 
  erred by not awarding her full attorney fees and costs.Â  We disagree.
The award of attorney fees is left to the discretion of the trial judge and 
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Smith v. 
  Smith, 308 S.C. 492, 496, 419 S.E.2d 232, 234-35 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  We find 
  the trial judge acted within her discretion in awarding Wife 75% of her attorney 
  fees and costs.Â  On remand from this court, the trial judge correctly considered 
  the factors for awarding attorney fees set out in Glasscock v. Glasscock, 
  304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991), particularly the beneficial results 
  obtained by Wifeâ€™s attorney.Â  Because the family court properly exercised its 
  discretion in awarding attorney fees, we affirm the award.
II. Post-Judgment Interest on the Attorney Fee Award
 Wife contends the family court erred by not awarding post-judgment 
  interest on her award of attorney fees.Â  We agree.
 In Casey v. Casey, 311 S.C. 243, 428 S.E.2d 714 (1993), the supreme 
  court held post-judgment interest should apply to equitable distribution awards.Â  
  Later, in Christy v. Christy, 317 S.C. 145, 452 S.E.2d 1 (Ct. App. 1994), 
  this court stated, â€œ[t]he cash award of attorneyâ€™s fees in this case is similar 
  to the fixed award of money in Casey and we see no reason to distinguish 
  the attorneyâ€™s fee award from the fixed equitable distribution money award.â€Â  
  Id. at 153, 452 S.E.2d at 5.Â  In Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 
  96, 529 S.E.2d 14 (2000), the supreme court established the rule for post-judgment 
  interest in a case involving equitable distribution.Â  The court held, â€œwhen 
  a money judgment is finalized, whether in a lower court or in an appellate court, 
  the interest on that amount, whether it has been modified upward or downward 
  or remains the same, runs from the date of the original judgment.â€Â  Id. 
  at 104, 529 S.E.2d at 19.Â  Based on the rule set out in Calhoun, and 
  the correlation made in Casey between attorney fees and equitable distribution 
  awards, we find Wife is entitled to post-judgment interest on her award of attorney 
  fees.
 South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(B) (Supp. 2002) provides all money decrees 
  shall draw interest at the rate of 12% per year.Â  However, this statute was 
  amended, effective January 1, 2001; therefore, the 12% interest rate only applies 
  to causes of action arising or accruing on or after January 1, 2001.Â  2000 S.C. 
  Act No. 344, Â§ 4.Â  Because this action arose prior to January 1, 2001, the applicable 
  interest rate is 14% per annum.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(B) (Supp. 
  2000).Â  Therefore, Wife is entitled to post-judgment interest on her attorneyâ€™s 
  fee award at the rate of 14% per annum from date of entry.Â  We remand this issue 
  to the family court for a calculation of the amount of post-judgment interest 
  Husband owes on the attorney fees award.Â  
III. Alimony 
Wife claims the family court erred in awarding her only $1,800 per month in 
  permanent periodic alimony.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn award of alimony rests within the sound discretion 
  of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  
  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 183-84, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 
  2001). â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support which is normally incident to 
  the marital relationship.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 
  S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988). â€œGenerally, alimony should place the supported 
  spouse, as nearly as practical, in the same position he or she enjoyed during 
  the marriage.â€ Allen, 347 S.C. at 184, 554 S.E.2d at 424. â€œIt is the 
  duty of the family court to make an alimony award that is fit, equitable, and 
  just if the claim is well founded.â€ Id. (citing Woodward v. Woodward, 
  294 S.C. 210, 217, 363 S.E.2d 413, 417 (Ct. App. 1987). TheÂ  trial court on 
  remand states it reviewed all factors (as required by case and statutory law).Â  
  We find the family court acted within its discretion in awarding Wife $1,800 
  per month permanent periodic alimony.Â  Considering the factors for making an 
  alimony award set out in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2002), especially 
  Wifeâ€™s bleak earning potential due to her outdated bookkeeping skills, compared 
  to Husbandâ€™s stable employment, we find the alimony award was proper.
Husband argues in his brief this court should impute 
  income to Wife.Â Â  Although Husband disagrees with the finding that Wife is unemployable, 
  he did not appeal the award of alimony. Therefore, we may not address Husbandâ€™s 
  argument.Â  
IV. Post-Judgment Interest on the Alimony Award 
Wife argues the family court erred by failing to award post-judgment 
  interest on the alimony arrearage from the date of the original order.Â  We agree.
We find Wife is entitled to post-judgment interest on the alimony award.Â  Husband 
  made seven payments totaling $32,400, which constitutes only eighteen alimony 
  payments, although thirty-two months had elapsed.Â  Therefore, Husband owes interest 
  on thirteen past-due alimony payments.Â  Interest is due on alimony at the time 
  each support payment becomes due.Â  See Thornton v. Thornton, 328 
  S.C. 96, 114, 492 S.E.2d 86, 96 (1997).Â  Accordingly, Wifeâ€™s post-judgment interest 
  on the alimony arrearage should be calculated from the date each payment was 
  due.Â  As stated above, according to 2000 S.C. Act No. 344, Â§ 4, the interest 
  rate on all money decrees regarding causes of action arising before January 
  1, 2001 is 14% per annum.Â  We remand this issue to the family court for a determination 
  of the amount of post-judgment interest Husband owes on the alimony arrearage.Â  

 V. Husbandâ€™s Entitlement to a Portion of Wifeâ€™s IRA 
Wife contends the family court erred in not taking additional testimony regarding 
  whether contributions to Wifeâ€™s IRA were marital and in finding Husband is entitled 
  to a portion of the IRA.Â  We find additional testimony was not needed on this 
  issue and it was not error to award Husband 50% of the marital funds in the 
  IRA.Â  Wife testified at the final hearing in 1999 that she contributed to her 
  IRA during the marriage in the amount of $1,500 per year for three years.Â  This 
  court specifically referred to this testimony in its 2001 opinion.Â  Clearly, 
  because these funds were contributed during the marriage, they are marital property 
  to which Husband is partially entitled.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-472 to -473 
  (Supp. 2002); Calhoun v. Calhoun, 331 S.C. 157, 175, 501 S.E.2d 735, 
  744-45 (Ct. App. 1998) (stating annuity in which wife invested during marriage 
  was part of marital estate and was subject to equitable distribution in divorce 
  action), affâ€™d in part, revâ€™d in part on other grounds, 339 S.C. 96, 
  529 S.E.2d 14 (2000).Â  Based on the above, we agree with the family court judgeâ€™s 
  finding that Husband is entitled to $2,250, or half of the marital property 
  in the IRA.Â  
Wife argues that if Husband is entitled to any 
  portion of Wifeâ€™s IRA, he is entitled to only the value of the marital 
  funds deposited, not the amount of funds deposited during the course 
  of the marriage. On remand, the family court determined it had correctly calculated 
  the amount of marital contributions made to the Wifeâ€™s IRA.Â  Husband refers 
  us to exhibits in the record showing that the value of the marital contributions 
  made to the IRA during the marriage was $9,308.89. That being the case, we fail 
  to see how Wife is prejudiced by the courtâ€™s finding that Husband is entitled 
  to only one-half of the amount of the contributions of $4,500.00.Â  Wife may 
  not complain of a ruling that does not prejudice her.Â  State v. Abney, 
  109 S.C. 102, 103, 95 S.E. 179, 180 (1918).
Husband argues he should receive more from the 
  IRA due to an additional $875 he claims was marital property.Â  Because Husband 
  did not appeal, we do not address this argument.
VI. Reimbursement to Husband 
Wife claims Husband is not entitled to the $4,222 reimbursement ordered by 
  the family court.Â  We find, while Husband is entitled to some reimbursement, 
  he is only entitled to one-half of the amount ordered by the family court.Â  

Husband paid $4,222.61 to redeem the marital home out of foreclosure and pay 
  the mortgage payments through December 2001.Â  Because the marital home is considered 
  marital property, both Husband and Wife were jointly responsible for making 
  the mortgage payments on the home.Â  Therefore, we find Husband is entitled to 
  $2,111 reimbursement from Wife.Â  We find this amount, which represents half 
  of the amount spent by Husband on the mortgage payments, is a fair reimbursement 
  to Husband because the expenses of the marital home, as marital property, should 
  be equally shared by Husband and Wife.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
CONNOR and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 545 S.E.2d 
    531 (Ct. App. 2001).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bynum Rayfield,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chester County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

 AFFIRMED

Opinion No. 3728
Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  27, 2004


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney Charles H. Richardson and 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold W. Coombs, Jr., of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  John R. Justice, of Chester, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Bynum Rayfield was charged 
  with three counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct, three counts of committing 
  a lewd act upon a child, and one count of contributing to the delinquency of 
  a minor.Â  The jury returned a verdict of guilty on all counts, and he was sentenced 
  to an aggregate term of thirty years imprisonment. Rayfield appeals, arguing 
  the circuit court erred in granting the Stateâ€™s Batson 
  [1]  motion and in charging the jury that the testimony of victims â€œneed 
  not be corroborated.â€Â  We affirm. 
  [2] 
FACTS
Rayfield was accused of sexually 
  abusing his two stepdaughters, hisÂ  daughter, and two neighborhood girls who 
  were friends with his stepdaughters and daughter.Â  All of the girls were minors 
  and testified as to Rayfieldâ€™s sexual misconduct.Â  Rayfield denied any misconduct.Â  
  The jury found Rayfield guilty of all charges, and he was sentenced.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Batson Issue
Rayfield argues the trial court erred in granting 
  the Stateâ€™s motion under Batson.Â  We agree, but we are constrained to 
  conclude that Rayfield ultimately was not legally prejudiced by the trial courtâ€™s 
  error.
During the initial jury selection, Rayfield, through 
  counsel, employed peremptory strikes against five prospective jurors.Â  Four 
  of the five prospective jurors struck were female.  [3] Â  The State introduced its Batson 
  objection by indicating that defense counsel should be required to put forward 
  a race and gender-neutral explanation for his strikes.Â  The State noted, â€œthat 
  of the selected jurors there are nine males [and] three females â€¦.â€  
  [4] Â  It further indicated that the motion â€œconcerned . . . the strikes 
  of the white females.â€Â  The State specifically identified Juror #17, a white 
  female, as â€œconcern[ing] the State the most.â€Â  
Defense counsel provided the trial court with 
  the basis for striking each of the prospective female jurors.Â  The trial court 
  deemed these explanations â€œrace and gender neutral.â€Â  As discussed more fully 
  below, the trial court found a Batson violation with respect to the only 
  male, Juror #70, struck by defense counsel. [5] Â  The first jury was quashed and â€œa redraw of 
  the juryâ€ followed.Â  
The ensuing â€œredrawâ€ resulted in no Batson 
  challenge, and significantly, none of the jurors struck by defense counsel during 
  the initial jury selection were seated on the second jury. [6] 
â€œThe Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth 
  Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a venire 
  person on the basis of race or gender.â€Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 
  615, 545 S.E.2d 805, 810 (2001).Â  The purpose of Batson is to â€œprotect 
  the defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial by a jury of the defendantâ€™s peers, protect 
  each venirepersonâ€™s right not to be excluded from jury service for discriminatory 
  reasons, and preserve public confidence in the fairness of our system of justice 
  by seeking to eradicate discrimination in the jury selection process.â€Â  State 
  v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 628-629, 515 S.E.2d 88, 90 (1999).Â  Both the State 
  and defendants are prohibited from discriminatorily exercising a peremptory 
  challenge of a prospective juror.Â  Georgia v. McCollum, 505 U.S. 42, 
  58 (1992).Â  The trial court must conduct a Batson hearing â€œwhen members 
  of a cognizable racial group or gender are struck and the opposing party requests 
  a hearing.â€Â  State v. Tucker, 334 S.C. 1, 8, 512 S.E.2d 99, 102 (1999).
Our supreme court has set forth the following 
  procedure for a Batson hearing:

After a party objects to a jury strike, the proponent of 
  the strike must offer a facially race-neutral [or gender-neutral] explanation.Â  
  This explanation is not required to be persuasive or even plausible.Â  Once the 
  proponent states a reason that is race-neutral [or gender-neutral], the burden 
  is on the party challenging the strike to show the explanation is mere pretext, 
  either by showing similarly situated members of another race [or the other gender] 
  were seated on the jury or the reason given for the strike is so fundamentally 
  implausible as to constitute mere pretext despite a lack of disparate treatment.

State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 59, 64, 512 S.E.2d 
  500, 503 (1999).Â  
Whether a Batson violation has occurred 
  must be determined by examining the totality of the circumstances, and â€œthe 
  opponent of the strike carries the ultimate burden of persuading the trial court 
  the challenged party exercised strikes in a discriminatory manner.â€Â  Shuler, 
  344 S.C. at 615, 545 S.E.2d at 810.Â  With regard to a Batson motion, 
  â€œ[a]ppellate courts give the trial courtâ€™s finding great deference on appeal, 
  and review the trial courtâ€™s ruling with a clearly erroneous standard.â€Â  Id.Â  
  When the record, however, does not support the reason upon which the trial court 
  has based his findings,Â  â€œthose findings will be overturned.â€Â  Tucker, 
  334 S.C. at 9, 512 S.E.2d at 103.
Rayfieldâ€™s counsel offered two reasons for striking 
  Juror #70:Â  (1) â€œhe was retired [and] I didnâ€™t have information from what he 
  was retired;â€ and (2) his â€œconservativeâ€ appearance.Â  
Here, the trial court followed the Stateâ€™s lead and 
  disregarded defense counselâ€™s explanation that he struck juror #70 due to his 
  conservativeÂ  appearance.Â  Our courts, as well as other jurisdictions, have 
  consistently found a prospective jurorâ€™s demeanor and appearance asÂ  nondiscriminatory 
  reasons for exercising a peremptory challenge of the juror.Â  See Tucker, 
  334 S.C. at 8, 512 S.E.2d at 102 (finding no violation of Batson where 
  State struck juror because he was argumentative and his answers were â€œdogmaticâ€); 
  State v. Wilder, 306 S.C. 535, 538, 413 S.E.2d 323, 325 (1991) (holding 
  that counsel may strike a juror based on demeanor and disposition); State 
  v. Smalls, 336 S.C. 301, 309, 519 S.E.2d 793, 797 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding 
  no discriminatory intent inherent in defense counselâ€™s explanation for striking 
  jurors who appeared to counsel as â€œlooking in a â€˜mean,â€™ â€˜sternâ€™ or â€˜accusatoryâ€™ 
  mannerâ€); State v. Guess, 318 S.C. 269, 273, 457 S.E.2dÂ  6, 8 (Ct. App. 
  1995) (noting that demeanor has been upheld in many jurisdictions as a legitimate 
  reason to strike a juror (citing Lockett v. State,Â  517 So.2d 1346 (Miss. 
  1987)); see also Jones v. State, No. 05-02-00357, 2003 WL 21649964, 
  at 3 (Tex. Crim. App. July 15, 2003) (upholding trial courtâ€™s denial of defendantâ€™s 
  Batson motion where Stateâ€™s explanation for striking juror was that the 
  juror wore leather clothing and had a â€œvery liberal outward appearanceâ€). 
Although not argued by the State, we note South Carolinaâ€™s 
  rejection of the â€œdual motivation doctrine in the Batson context.â€Â  See 
  Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. 51, 59, 495 S.E.2d 205, 210 (1998) (noting 
  that South Carolina follows the â€œtaintedâ€ approach whereby a discriminatory 
  explanation for the exercise of a preemptory challenge will vitiate other nondiscriminatory 
  explanations for the strike).Â  Consequently, Rayfieldâ€™s counselâ€™s stated reliance 
  on the appearance of Juror #70 will not cure a discriminatory purpose.Â  The 
  question then becomes whether, under our deferential standard of review, the 
  record sustains the trial courtâ€™s determination that Juror #70 was struck because 
  of his gender.Â  We find the record contains no evidence indicating Juror #70 
  was struck because he is a male.
The Stateâ€™s disjointed and moving-target approach to 
  its Batson motion created confusion.Â  The State began its motion with 
  a reference to Juror #17, a white female, requesting a â€œrace and gender-neutral 
  explanationâ€ for the strike.Â  On the heels of informing the trial court that 
  its focus was the striking of white females, the State mentioned Juror #70, 
  the sole male struck by defense counsel.Â  The colloquy returned to the gravamen 
  of the Stateâ€™s Batson motion, the striking of females, especially Juror 
  #17 which â€œconcern[ed] the state the most.â€Â  During the argument, the State 
  repeatedly assigned discriminatory motives to defense counsel in striking females.Â  
  When the trial court determined that defense counselâ€™s reasons for striking 
  the females were nondiscriminatory, the State resurrected its challenge to Juror 
  #70.Â  Defense counsel reiterated his position that â€œjuror [#70] appeared to 
  be a very conservative individual, to me . . . he just appeared fromÂ  appearance 
  that he would be the type likely to side with the State.â€Â  The trial court ignored 
  defense counselâ€™s reliance on this jurorâ€™s conservative appearance and granted 
  the Stateâ€™s Batson motion, finding Juror #70 was struck because he was 
  a male: â€œThe only reason given for striking Juror #70 â€¦ is that he was retired 
  â€¦ but you allowed Juror #36 [a female] to serve [who was also retired] â€¦ Iâ€™m 
  going to find that [in regard to Juror #70] that was not a gender neutral reason.â€Â  

As noted, the first jury was comprised of nine males 
  and three females.Â  Defense counsel used the allotted number of strikes, exercising 
  all but one against females.Â  Clearly, Rayfieldâ€™s counsel was not discriminating 
  against males.Â  The totality of the facts and circumstances compels a finding 
  that no gender based discrimination was associated with the striking of Juror 
  #70. Defense counsel asserted to the trial court: â€œ[T]heyâ€™re complaining I was 
  striking all these females and seating all these men, and then thereâ€™s one man 
  I strike â€¦ [and] out of all these jurors, itâ€™s certainly not a pattern of discrimination 
  against men.â€Â  We agree and find absolutely no gender based discrimination in 
  the exercise of a preemptory challenge against Juror #70.Â  We therefore find 
  that the reasons asserted for the strike of Juror #70 were gender neutral, and 
  the State fell short of demonstrating purposeful gender based discrimination.Â  
  It was error for the trial court to grant the Stateâ€™s Batson motion.Â  

We nevertheless find no reversible error pursuant to 
  the supreme court precedent of State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 
  366 (1996).Â  In Adams, the trial court erred in granting the Stateâ€™s 
  Batson motion and quashing the jury.Â  Because the jury ultimately selected 
  had none of the persons defense counsel struck from the first jury panel, the 
  supreme court found â€œno prejudice resulted from the judgeâ€™s errorâ€ and affirmed 
  Adamsâ€™ convictions.Â  Id. at 126, 480 S.E.2d at 373.Â  In so holding, the 
  court in Adams recognized that no jurorâ€™s equal protection rights are 
  violated where the trial court improperly quashes a jury panel.Â  In addition, 
  the court in Adams referenced the settled principle that â€œ[a] defendant 
  has no right to trial by any particular jury.â€ Id.Â  But cf.Â  
  Ford, 334 S.C. at 66, 512 S.E.2d at 504 (holding that reversal and granting 
  of a new trial is a proper remedy where the trial court erred in finding defendant 
  violated Batson in striking certain jurors and any challenged 
  juror was seated on the second jury). [7] 
II. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Charge Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann.Â§16-3-657
Rayfield argues the trial court erred in charging the jury 
  that the testimony of the victims â€œneed not be corroboratedâ€ pursuant to S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-657 (Supp. 2002). We disagree.
The trial court is required to charge the correct 
  law of South Carolina.Â  State v. Peer, 320 S.C. 546, 553, 466 S.E.2d 
  375, 380 (1996).Â  Jury instructions should be considered as a whole, and if 
  as a whole they are free from error, any isolated portions which may be misleading 
  do not constitute reversible error.Â  State v. Sims, 304 S.C. 409, 422, 
  405 S.E.2d 384 (1991).Â  The substance of the law is what must be instructed 
  to the jury, not any particular verbiage.Â  State v. Rabon, 275 S.C. 459, 
  462, 272 S.E.2d 634, 636 (1980).
The trial court instructed 
  the jury that section 16-3-657 provides that â€œthe testimony of a victim need 
  not be corroborated.â€Â  The challenged charge withstood appellate scrutiny in 
  State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 509, 435 S.E.2d 859, 863 (1993).Â  We 
  consequently find no reversible error in the trial courtâ€™s instruction to the 
  jury regarding the corroboration of the victimsâ€™ testimony.Â  Consistent with 
  Schumpert, we note the trial court: (1) properly instructed the jury 
  that they were the sole finders of fact with the discretion to determine the 
  credibility of the witnesses; (2) correctly charged our stateâ€™s constitutional 
  mandate prohibiting the court from commenting on the facts and stated: â€œThe 
  law does not permit me to have an opinion about the facts in this case;â€Â  and 
  (3) correctly charged the Stateâ€™s burden of proof.Â  While the section 16-3-657 
  charge is not mandatory, such charge does not constitute reversible error when 
  the Schumpert safeguards are present.
CONCLUSION
Having determined that Rayfieldâ€™s appeal is controlled 
  by the supreme court precedent of State v. Adams and State v. Schumpert, 
  respectively, the judgment of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J.,Â  and HOWARD, J., concur.Â  

 
   
    [1] Â  Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79, 106 S.Ct. 1712, 90 L.Ed. 
    2d 69 (1986).

 
   
    [2] Â  Rayfieldâ€™s appellate counsel did not represent Rayfield at trial.

 
   
    [3]  Defense counsel struck an additional female prospective juror during 
    selection of alternate jurors. In total, Rayfieldâ€™s trial counsel struck six 
    prospective jurors, five of whom are female.

 
   
    [4]  The first jury was comprised of eight blacks and four whites.Â  The 
    first alternate is a white male, and the second alternate is a black female.

 
   
    [5]  While Juror #70 was the only male struck by the defense, the State 
    struck only males.

 
   
    [6]  Defense counsel struck two of the four females who were successfully 
    challenged in the initial jury selection process.Â  Juror #70 was not drawn 
    for the second jury.Â  The second jury was comprised of eight whites and four 
    blacks, and the gender makeup was altered as well, as the second jury was 
    comprised of seven males and five females.

 
   
    [7] Â  We acknowledge Rayfieldâ€™s concern with the loss of a properly selected 
    jury, and the concomitant desire of the State to avoid a particular jury for 
    a variety of reasons connected to the Stateâ€™s perceptions of its chances of 
    obtaining a guilty verdict.Â Â  The application of the holding in Adams 
    may, in some cases, allow the State to benefit from its pursuit of a meritless 
    Batson motion by providing it with another opportunity to draw a jury 
    more to its liking.Â  We are, however, bound to apply the holding in Adams.

description: Vincent A. Vogt appeals from an adverse jury verdict in a personal injury action.    The dispositive issue on appeal is Vogtâ€™s status as a licensee or an invitee.  The trial court ruled that Vogt was a mere social guest and hence a licensee.  The court of appeals affirms.
text:
Vogt v. Murraywood Swim


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Vincent A. Vogt, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Murraywood Swim and Racquet Club, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
  Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3729
  Heard December 9, 2003 â€“ Filed January 27, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Frank Anthony Barton and H. Wayne Floyd, both of W. Columbia, for Appellant.
        Thomas C. Salane and R. Hawthorne Barrett, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Vincent A. Vogt appeals 
  from an adverse jury verdict in a personal injury action.Â Â Â  The dispositive 
  issue on appeal is Vogtâ€™s status as a licensee or an invitee.Â  The trial court 
  ruled that Vogt was a mere social guest and hence a licensee.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Vogt was injured as a result of a diving board/swimming pool accident at the 
  Murraywood Swim and Racket Club (â€œMurraywoodâ€).Â  He commenced this action asserting 
  causes of action for negligence and strict liability. 
  [1]  Â Murraywood answered denying liability and alleging various 
  defenses, including comparative negligence.
Murraywood is a private, nonprofit pool and tennis 
  facility operated by and for a group of homeowners in Lexington County.Â  The 
  facility is equally co-owned by its members.Â  The facility is not open 
  to the public at large, for it only allows non-members to use the facilities 
  in two situations.Â  Non-members may either rent the facilities for private use, 
  or attend as a guest of a member.Â  
On June 28, 1998, Vogt was invited to Murraywood as a social guest of Don Pevey 
  and Lynne Soobitsky.Â  After consuming alcohol at the home of Pevey and Soobitsky, 
  the group walked to the pool.Â  Vogt decided to dive into the pool via Murraywoodâ€™s 
  three-meter high diving board. Â His first dive went without incident.Â  Approximately 
  thirty minutes later, Vogt decided to attempt a swan dive off the same diving 
  board.Â  After entering the water, Vogt struck his head on the bottom of the 
  pool and was injured. Â This action followed.
The Murraywood pool was constructed in 1975.Â  Before 
  trial, Murraywood made a motion in limine seeking to establish 
  that operation of the pool was controlled by regulations promulgated in 1971 
  by the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental ControlÂ  (â€œDHECâ€).Â  
  Vogt sought to introduce more recent DHEC standards as well as standards promulgated 
  by other organizations as evidence of a common law standard of care.Â  The trial 
  court found that the 1971 DHEC regulations were the only applicable regulations 
  concerning the operation of the Murraywood pool.Â  It nevertheless permitted 
  Vogtâ€™s expert, in rendering his opinion, to rely on and reference the more recent 
  DHEC regulations and industry standards.
Before instructing the jury, the trial judge ruled 
  that Vogt was a licensee.Â  As such, she declined to charge the jury with the 
  law applicable to an invitee.Â  The trial court further refused Vogtâ€™s request 
  to specifically charge the DHEC standards other than those in effect at the 
  time the pool was constructed in 1975, although the court expressly authorized 
  the jury to consider the opinion testimony of expert witnesses.Â  Vogtâ€™s expert 
  witness relied on more recent DHEC regulations and current industry standards.

  ISSUES 
  
    
      I.
         
      Did the trial court err in concluding as a 
        matter of law that Vogt was a licensee?
      
    
    
      II.
      Did 
        the trial court err in refusing to charge certain â€œrequests to charge,â€ 
        including the law relating to an invitee and post-1971 DHEC regulations?
    
  
  
  LAW/ANALYSIS

I. Invitee/Licensee 
Vogt argues it was error for 
  the trial court to rule that he was a licensee as a matter of law.Â  Acknowledging 
  that the facts are not in dispute and that a question of law is presented, Vogt 
  maintains he was an invitee.Â  Specifically, Vogt contends that because Murraywood 
  typically charged non-members a two-dollar admission fee, and limited the number 
  of times a guest could visit, the operation of the Murraywood pool facility 
  is analogous to a business charging admission.Â  We disagree.Â  
The South Carolina Supreme Court has defined a licensee 
  as â€œa person who is privileged to enter upon land by virtue of the possessorâ€™s 
  consent.â€Â  Neil v. Byrum, 288 S.C. 472, 473, 343 S.E.2d 615, 616 (1986); 
  see also Sims v. Giles, 343 S.C. 708, 720, 541 S.E.2d 857, 864 
  (Ct. App. 2001); and F.P. Hubbard & R.L. Felix, The South Carolina Law 
  of Torts 111 (2d ed.1997).Â  When a licensee enters onto the property of 
  another, it is for his or her benefit and not that of the landowner.Â  Sims, 
  343 S.C. at 720, 541 S.E.2d at 863.Â  The duties a landowner owes to a licensee 
  are to use reasonable care to (a) â€œdiscover him and avoid injury to him in carrying 
  on activities upon the landâ€; and (b) â€œwarn him of any concealed dangerous conditions 
  or activities which are known to the possessor.â€Â  Neil, 288 S.C. at 473, 
  343 S.E.2d at 616 (citations ommitted).Â  
By contrast, â€œ[a]n invitee is a person who comes on 
  the premises with express or implied permission and for the purpose of benefiting 
  the owner/occupier.â€Â  Hubbard & Felix at 112; Sims, 343 S.C. at 713, 
  541 S.E.2d at 860.Â  A landowner owes an invitee a duty of due to care to discover 
  risks and to warn of or make safe existing unreasonable risks.Â  Hubbard & 
  Felix at 114.Â Â  
In Neil, the supreme court held that a social guest is a licensee.Â  
  Neil, 288 S.C. at 473, 343 S.E.2d at 616 (citations omitted).Â  Comment 
  three to the Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 330(h) (1965) further explains 
  the distinction between social guests/licensees and invitees:

  Some confusion has resulted from the fact that, although a social guest normally 
    is invited, and even urged to come, he is not an â€œinvitee,â€ within the legal 
    meaning of that term, as stated in Â§ 332.Â  He does not come as a member of 
    the public upon premises held open to the public for that purpose, and he 
    does not enter for a purpose directly or indirectly connected with the business 
    dealings of the possessor.Â  The use of the premises is extended to him merely 
    as a personal favor to him.

In Landry v. Hilton Head Prop. 
  Owners Assâ€™n, 317 S.C. 200, 202, 452 S.E.2d 619, 620 (Ct. App. 1994), a 
  homeowner was injured while walking in the common areas of her gated community.Â  
  This court held that because Landry was a dues-paying member of the property 
  ownersâ€™ association, she had the right to use the common areas without 
  the associationâ€™s permission.Â  Id. at 204, 452 S.E.2d at 621.Â  As such, 
  she was characterized as an invitee.Â  Id.Â  Conversely, we believe that 
  a guest of a dues-paying member enters not by right, but by the permission of
